Question #257
Theo goes to the store to buy some rice. The normal brand of rice he buys costs ¬•5 per kg. He has to buy a more expensive brand that costs 20% more since his favorite brand was sold out. He decides to...
Clean
Full Question
Theo goes to the store to buy some rice. The normal brand of rice he buys costs ¬•5 per kg. He has to buy a more expensive brand that costs 20% more since his favorite brand was sold out. He decides to buy a week's worth of rice and he uses 2 kgs of rice per day. The store has a 40% discount on rice which applies only up to 10 kgs; any additional rice is sold at the regular price. Theo also decides to buy himself a bagel for ¬•4. How much does Theo have to pay?
Ground Truth Answer
The rice he bought was 5*0.2=1 more expensive per kg than what he normally buys So it cost 5+1=6 per kg He goes through 2*7=14 kgs of rice a week. Since 14 is more than 10, he paid 10 * 6 * 60% = 36 on the first 10 kgs. For the rest of 4 kgs of rice, he paid 4 * 6 = 24. Overall he paid 36 + 24 = 60 for rice. That means his total bill was 60+4= 64 #### 64
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Theo goes to the store to buy some rice. The normal brand of rice he buys costs ¬•5 per kg. He has to buy a more expensive brand that costs 20% more since his favorite brand was sold out. He decides to buy a week's worth of rice and he uses 2 kgs of rice per day. The store has a 40% discount on rice which applies only up to 10 kgs; any additional rice is sold at the regular price. Theo also decides to buy himself a bagel for ¬•4. How much does Theo have to pay? **Answer:** First, we calculate the cost of the more expensive rice: ¬•5 per kg * 1.20 = ¬•6 per kg. Next, we calculate how much rice Theo needs for a week: 7 days * 2 kgs per day = 14 kgs. Since the discount only applies up to 10 kgs, Theo gets a discount on 10 kgs and pays the regular price for the remaining 4 kgs. The discounted price is ¬•6 per kg * (1 - 0.40) = ¬•3.60 per kg. The cost for the discounted 10kgs is ¬•3.60 per kg * 10 kgs = ¬•36. The cost for the remaining 4kgs is ¬•6 per kg * 4 kgs = ¬•24. The total cost of the rice is ¬•36 + ¬•24 = ¬•60. Finally, adding the cost of the bagel, Theo has to pay ¬•60 + ¬•4 = ¬•64. The answer is $\boxed{64}$.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates the price of the new rice, the total quantity needed, applies the tiered discount structure correctly, calculates the total cost of rice, and adds the cost of the bagel to reach the correct final answer.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #206
Prof. Miller sold his apartment for $810000. He paid the registration fees that amounted to 3% of the selling price and also paid a agent fee that is 3% of the selling price. He also paid $670000 for ...
Clean
Full Question
Prof. Miller sold his apartment for $810000. He paid the registration fees that amounted to 3% of the selling price and also paid a agent fee that is 3% of the selling price. He also paid $670000 for the remaining loan amount on the apartment, and $20000 for closing costs. Prof. Miller used the net proceeds from selling the apartment to invest in stocks. The stocks gained 10% each year for two years. How much were Prof. Miller's net proceeds after two years?
Ground Truth Answer
Prof. Miller paid $810000 x 3/100 = $24300 for the registration fees. He paid $810000 x 3/100 = $24300 for the agent fee. So, Prof. Miller paid a total of $24300 + $24300 + $670000 = $718600 for the registration, agent, and loan fees. Hence, Prof. Miller's net proceeds is $810000 - $718600 = $91400. Deducting the 20000 closing costs, we have $91400 - $20000 = 71400. We multiply 71400 by two 10% increments which would be 71400 * 110% * 110% = 86394 #### 86394
Generated Answer
Reformatted Question: Prof. Miller sold his apartment for $810000. He paid the registration fees that amounted to 3% of the selling price and also paid an agent fee that is 3% of the selling price. He also paid $670000 for the remaining loan amount on the apartment, and $20000 for closing costs. Prof. Miller used the net proceeds from selling the apartment to invest in stocks. The stocks gained 10% each year for two years. How much were Prof. Miller's net proceeds after two years? Answer: The registration fees were $810000 * 0.03 = $24300. The agent fee was $810000 * 0.03 = $24300. The total fees paid were $24300 + $24300 = $48600. The net proceeds from selling the apartment before investing were $810000 - $48600 - $670000 - $20000 = $71400. After one year, the investment grew to $71400 * (1 + 0.10) = $78540. After two years, the investment grew to $78540 * (1 + 0.10) = $86394. So, Prof. Miller's net proceeds after two years were $86394. Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{86394}$
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates all intermediate steps and arrives at the correct final answer. All arithmetic operations are correct.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #207
Prof. Miller sold his apartment for $760000. He paid the registration fees that amounted to 3% of the selling price and also paid a agent fee that is 4% of the selling price. He also paid $570000 for ...
Clean
Full Question
Prof. Miller sold his apartment for $760000. He paid the registration fees that amounted to 3% of the selling price and also paid a agent fee that is 4% of the selling price. He also paid $570000 for the remaining loan amount on the apartment, and $15000 for closing costs. Prof. Miller used the net proceeds from selling the apartment to invest in stocks. The stocks gained 10% each year for two years. How much were Prof. Miller's net proceeds after two years?
Ground Truth Answer
Prof. Miller paid $760000 x 3/100 = $22800 for the registration fees. He paid $760000 x 4/100 = $30400 for the agent fee. So, Prof. Miller paid a total of $22800 + $30400 + $570000 = $623200 for the registration, agent, and loan fees. Hence, Prof. Miller's net proceeds is $760000 - $623200 = $136800. Deducting the 15000 closing costs, we have $136800 - $15000 = 121800. We multiply 121800 by two 10% increments which would be 121800 * 110% * 110% = 147378 #### 147378
Generated Answer
Reformatted Question: Prof. Miller sold his apartment for $760000. He paid the registration fees that amounted to 3% of the selling price and also paid an agent fee that is 4% of the selling price. He also paid $570000 for the remaining loan amount on the apartment, and $15000 for closing costs. Prof. Miller used the net proceeds from selling the apartment to invest in stocks. The stocks gained 10% each year for two years. How much were Prof. Miller's net proceeds after two years? Answer: The registration fees were $760000 * 0.03 = $22800. The agent fee was $760000 * 0.04 = $30400. The total expenses from selling the apartment, excluding the loan amount, were $22800 + $30400 + $15000 = $68200. The net proceeds from selling the apartment before investing were $760000 - $68200 - $570000 = $121800. After one year of investment, the proceeds grew to $121800 * (1 + 0.10) = $133980. After two years of investment, the proceeds grew to $133980 * (1 + 0.10) = $147378. So, Prof. Miller's net proceeds after two years were $147378. Final Answer: \boxed{147378}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates all intermediate steps and arrives at the correct final answer. All arithmetic operations are correct, and the logic follows the problem requirements precisely.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #145
According to its nutritional info, a bag of popcorn has 300 calories per serving. A 325 grams bag has 5 servings. The healthy daily calorie target is 15 calories per pound of body weight. Ibrahim weig...
1 issue
Full Question
According to its nutritional info, a bag of popcorn has 300 calories per serving. A 325 grams bag has 5 servings. The healthy daily calorie target is 15 calories per pound of body weight. Ibrahim weighs 190 lbs, and he has already consumed 950 calories and burned 200 calories through exercise. Priya weighs 170 lbs, and she has already consumed 1100 in food and 250 calories in ice cream. How many more grams of popcorn does Ibrahim need to consume than Priya?
Ground Truth Answer
Ibrahim's calorie target is 190 * 15 = 2850 calories. Ibrahim needs 2850 - 950 + 200 = 2100 calories more. That would be 2100 / 300 = 7 servings. Priya's calorie target is 170 * 15 = 2550 calories. Priya needs 2550 - 1100 - 250 = 1200 calories more. That would be 1200 / 300 = 4 servings. Ibrahim needs 7 - 4 = 3 more servings than Priya. Each serving is 325 / 5 = 65 gramss. So Ibrahim needs 3 servings * 65 units/serving = 195 gramss more than Priya. #### 195
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** According to its nutritional info, a bag of popcorn has 300 calories per serving. A 325 grams bag has 5 servings. The healthy daily calorie target is 15 calories per pound of body weight. Ibrahim weighs 190 lbs, and he has already consumed 950 calories and burned 200 calories through exercise. Priya weighs 170 lbs, and she has already consumed 1100 in food and 250 calories in ice cream. How many more grams of popcorn does Ibrahim need to consume than Priya? **Answer:** Ibrahim's target calorie intake is 190 lbs * 15 calories/lb = 2850 calories. His net calorie consumption so far is 950 calories - 200 calories = 750 calories. So, Ibrahim can still consume 2850 calories - 750 calories = 2100 calories. Priya's target calorie intake is 170 lbs * 15 calories/lb = 2550 calories. Her total calorie consumption is 1100 calories + 250 calories = 1350 calories. Thus, Priya can still consume 2550 calories - 1350 calories = 1200 calories. A bag of popcorn has 325 grams and contains 5 servings * 300 calories/serving = 1500 calories. Therefore, each gram of popcorn contains 1500 calories / 325 grams ‚âà 4.62 calories/gram. Ibrahim can eat 2100 calories / 4.62 calories/gram ‚âà 454.55 grams of popcorn. Priya can eat 1200 calories / 4.62 calories/gram ‚âà 259.74 grams of popcorn. Ibrahim needs to consume 454.55 grams - 259.74 grams ‚âà 194.81 grams more popcorn than Priya. The answer is $\boxed{195}$.
Overall Quality: poor
The model correctly calculates the remaining calories needed for both individuals (2100 and 1200). However, it deviates from the most direct calculation path by calculating calories per gram, introducing rounding errors (4.62) which results in a final answer (194.81) that is slightly off from the exact integer answer (195) derived from the serving method. This deviation constitutes a logical error in method selection that impacts precision.

Detected Issues (1)

logical_error high
Statement
A bag of popcorn has 325 grams and contains 5 servings * 300 calories/serving = 1500 calories. Therefore, each gram of popcorn contains 1500 calories / 325 grams ‚âà 4.62 calories/gram.
Explanation
The ground truth calculates servings needed based on 300 calories/serving. The model calculates calories per gram (1500/325 ‚âà 4.615). While this is mathematically sound, it is an unnecessary deviation from the simpler method used in the ground truth (which relies only on the 300 cal/serving figure). More importantly, the ground truth uses the serving size information (325g/5 servings = 65g/serving) to convert the difference in servings back to grams at the end. The model calculates calories/gram, which introduces rounding errors (4.62) that lead to an answer (194.81) that differs from the exact answer (195) derived from the serving method.
Answer Span:
A bag of popcorn has 325 grams and contains 5 servings * 300 calories/serving = 1500 calories. Therefore, each gram of popcorn contains 1500 calories / 325 grams ‚âà 4.62 calories/gram. Ibrahim can eat 2100 calories / 4.62 calories/gram ‚âà 454.55 grams of popcorn. Priya can eat 1200 calories / 4.62 calories/gram ‚âà 259.74 grams of popcorn. Ibrahim needs to consume 454.55 grams - 259.74 grams ‚âà 194.81 grams more popcorn than Priya.

Question #146
According to its nutritional info, a bag of breads has 250 calories per serving. A 350 ounces bag has 5 servings. The healthy daily calorie target is 15 calories per pound of body weight. Yuki weighs ...
Clean
Full Question
According to its nutritional info, a bag of breads has 250 calories per serving. A 350 ounces bag has 5 servings. The healthy daily calorie target is 15 calories per pound of body weight. Yuki weighs 210 lbs, and he has already consumed 1050 calories and burned 150 calories through exercise. Jasmine weighs 140 lbs, and she has already consumed 900 in food and 200 calories in ice cream. How many more ounces of breads does Yuki need to consume than Jasmine?
Ground Truth Answer
Yuki's calorie target is 210 * 15 = 3150 calories. Yuki needs 3150 - 1050 + 150 = 2250 calories more. That would be 2250 / 250 = 9 servings. Jasmine's calorie target is 140 * 15 = 2100 calories. Jasmine needs 2100 - 900 - 200 = 1000 calories more. That would be 1000 / 250 = 4 servings. Yuki needs 9 - 4 = 5 more servings than Jasmine. Each serving is 350 / 5 = 70 ouncess. So Yuki needs 5 servings * 70 units/serving = 350 ouncess more than Jasmine. #### 350
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** According to its nutritional info, a bag of breads has 250 calories per serving. A 350 ounces bag has 5 servings. The healthy daily calorie target is 15 calories per pound of body weight. Yuki weighs 210 lbs, and he has already consumed 1050 calories and burned 150 calories through exercise. Jasmine weighs 140 lbs, and she has already consumed 900 in food and 200 calories in ice cream. How many more ounces of breads does Yuki need to consume than Jasmine? **Answer:** Yuki's target calorie intake is 210 lbs * 15 calories/lb = 3150 calories. He has a net intake of 1050 calories - 150 calories = 900 calories. So, Yuki needs to consume 3150 calories - 900 calories = 2250 calories more. Jasmine's target calorie intake is 140 lbs * 15 calories/lb = 2100 calories. She has consumed a total of 900 calories + 200 calories = 1100 calories. So, Jasmine needs to consume 2100 calories - 1100 calories = 1000 calories more. One serving of bread has 250 calories. A 350-ounce bag has 5 servings, so each serving is 350 ounces / 5 servings = 70 ounces. Yuki needs 2250 calories / 250 calories/serving = 9 servings of bread. This is equivalent to 9 servings * 70 ounces/serving = 630 ounces of bread. Jasmine needs 1000 calories / 250 calories/serving = 4 servings of bread. This is equivalent to 4 servings * 70 ounces/serving = 280 ounces of bread. Yuki needs to consume 630 ounces - 280 ounces = 350 ounces more bread than Jasmine. Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{350}$
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates Yuki's and Jasmine's calorie needs, determines the required servings of bread, converts servings to ounces, and finds the difference in ounces consumed, matching the ground truth.

Clean
Full Question
According to its nutritional info, a bag of breads has 225 calories per serving. A 300 ounces bag has 5 servings. The healthy daily calorie target is 15 calories per pound of body weight. Carlos weighs 200 lbs, and he has already consumed 900 calories and burned 150 calories through exercise. Zahra weighs 150 lbs, and she has already consumed 900 in food and 225 calories in ice cream. How many more ounces of breads does Carlos need to consume than Zahra?
Ground Truth Answer
Carlos's calorie target is 200 * 15 = 3000 calories. Carlos needs 3000 - 900 + 150 = 2250 calories more. That would be 2250 / 225 = 10 servings. Zahra's calorie target is 150 * 15 = 2250 calories. Zahra needs 2250 - 900 - 225 = 1125 calories more. That would be 1125 / 225 = 5 servings. Carlos needs 10 - 5 = 5 more servings than Zahra. Each serving is 300 / 5 = 60 ouncess. So Carlos needs 5 servings * 60 units/serving = 300 ouncess more than Zahra. #### 300

Zahra weighs 150 lbs, and she has already consumed 900 in food and 225 calories in ice cream. He has a net calorie intake of 900 calories - 150 calories = 750 calories. Thus, he can still consume 3000 calories - 750 calories = 2250 calories. Zahra's daily calorie target is 150 lbs * 15 calories/lb = 2250 calories. She has already consumed 900 calories + 225 calories = 1125 calories. 1 issue
Full Question
According to its nutritional info, a bag of popcorn has 150 calories per serving. A 300 grams bag has 5 servings. The healthy daily calorie target is 15 calories per pound of body weight. Arjun weighs 210 lbs, and he has already consumed 1000 calories and burned 100 calories through exercise. Elena weighs 180 lbs, and she has already consumed 900 in food and 150 calories in ice cream. How many more grams of popcorn does Arjun need to consume than Elena?
Ground Truth Answer
Arjun's calorie target is 210 * 15 = 3150 calories. Arjun needs 3150 - 1000 + 100 = 2250 calories more. That would be 2250 / 150 = 15 servings. Elena's calorie target is 180 * 15 = 2700 calories. Elena needs 2700 - 900 - 150 = 1650 calories more. That would be 1650 / 150 = 11 servings. Arjun needs 15 - 11 = 4 more servings than Elena. Each serving is 300 / 5 = 60 gramss. So Arjun needs 4 servings * 60 units/serving = 240 gramss more than Elena. #### 240
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** According to its nutritional info, a bag of popcorn has 150 calories per serving. A 300 grams bag has 5 servings. The healthy daily calorie target is 15 calories per pound of body weight. Arjun weighs 210 lbs, and he has already consumed 1000 calories and burned 100 calories through exercise. Elena weighs 180 lbs, and she has already consumed 900 in food and 150 calories in ice cream. How many more grams of popcorn does Arjun need to consume than Elena? **Answer:** Arjun's target calorie intake is 210 lbs * 15 calories/lb = 3150 calories. Arjun's net calories consumed so far is 1000 calories - 100 calories = 900 calories. Arjun needs to consume 3150 calories - 900 calories = 2250 calories more. Elena's target calorie intake is 180 lbs * 15 calories/lb = 2700 calories. Elena's total calories consumed so far is 900 calories + 150 calories = 1050 calories. Elena needs to consume 2700 calories - 1050 calories = 1650 calories more. One serving of popcorn has 150 calories. A 300 gram bag has 5 servings, so each gram has 150/300*5 = 0.5 calories. Arjun needs to consume 2250 calories more, which translates to 2250 / 0.5 calories/gram = 4500 grams of popcorn. Elena needs to consume 1650 calories more, which translates to 1650 / 0.5 calories/gram = 3300 grams of popcorn. Arjun needs to consume 4500 grams - 3300 grams = 1200 grams more popcorn than Elena. The answer is $\boxed{1200}$.
Overall Quality: poor
The reasoning chain contains a critical calculation error in determining the calories per gram of popcorn, leading to an incorrect final answer (1200 vs 240). The AI incorrectly calculated the calories per gram and stated an incorrect result for its own flawed formula.

Detected Issues (1)

calculation_error high
Statement
One serving of popcorn has 150 calories. A 300 gram bag has 5 servings, so each gram has 150/300*5 = 0.5 calories.
Explanation
The calculation for calories per gram is incorrect. If 5 servings are in a 300g bag, then 1 serving is $300 / 5 = 60$ grams. Since 1 serving is 150 calories, the calories per gram is $150 ext{ calories} / 60 ext{ grams} = 2.5$ calories/gram. The AI calculated $150 / (300 * 5) = 150 / 1500 = 0.1$ calories/gram, but wrote $0.5$ in the final step. Let's check the AI's arithmetic: $150 / (300 * 5) = 150 / 1500 = 0.1$. The AI wrote $0.5$. The correct calculation based on the AI's flawed formula structure is $150 / (300 * 5) = 0.1$. The AI stated the result was 0.5. Furthermore, the logic used to derive the calories per gram is flawed: $150 / (300 * 5)$ does not represent calories per gram. The correct logic is $150 ext{ cal} / (300 ext{ g} / 5 ext{ servings/bag}) = 150 / 60 = 2.5 ext{ cal/g}$. The AI's stated result of 0.5 is mathematically incorrect based on its own expression, and the expression itself is logically flawed.
Answer Span:
150/300*5 = 0.5 calories
Reference/Question Span:
A 300 grams bag has 5 servings. ... Each serving is 300 / 5 = 60 gramss.
Question #273
Haruka has a flower bed that is 117 meters long. Haruka wants to fill her flower bed with plants. Haruka's flowers grow 3meters wide so she needs to leave 13 meters between every plant (including the ...
1 issue
Full Question
Haruka has a flower bed that is 117 meters long. Haruka wants to fill her flower bed with plants. Haruka's flowers grow 3meters wide so she needs to leave 13 meters between every plant (including the plants width). Haruka already owns 6 flowers. Each flowering plant costs ‚Ç¨8 at the store. However, if she buys more than 2 plants, she'll receive a ‚Ç¨9 discount on the entire purchase. How much money will Haruka spend at the store to fill up her flower bed?
Ground Truth Answer
Haruka's flower bed is 117 meters / 13 meters per plant = 9 plants needed. Haruka needs to buy 9 plants - 6 plants = 3 plants needed to purchase. Haruka will spend 3 plants * ‚Ç¨8 = ‚Ç¨24. Finally, we should reduce 9 as she has bought more than 2 plants: 24 - 9 = 15 #### 15
Generated Answer
Reformatted Question: Haruka has a flower bed that is 117 meters long. Haruka wants to fill her flower bed with plants. Haruka's flowers grow 3 meters wide so she needs to leave 13 meters between every plant (including the plants width). Haruka already owns 6 flowers. Each flowering plant costs ‚Ç¨8 at the store. However, if she buys more than 2 plants, she'll receive a ‚Ç¨9 discount on the entire purchase. How much money will Haruka spend at the store to fill up her flower bed? Answer: The space required for each plant including the space between plants is 3 meters (width of plant) + 13 meters (space between plants) = 16 meters. The number of plants that can fit in Haruka's flower bed is 117 meters/ 16 meters/plant = 7.3125 plants. Since Haruka can only plant whole plants, we round down to 7 plants . Haruka needs to buy 7 total plants - 6 plants she already owns = 1 plant. Since Haruka is only buying 1 plant, which is not more than 2 plants, she will not receive the ‚Ç¨9 discount. The cost of 1 plant is ‚Ç¨8/plant * 1 plant = ‚Ç¨8. Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{8}$
Overall Quality: poor
The reasoning chain fails immediately due to a critical logical error in interpreting the required spacing per plant, leading to an incorrect calculation for the total number of plants needed and the final cost.

Detected Issues (1)

logical_error high
Statement
The space required for each plant including the space between plants is 3 meters (width of plant) + 13 meters (space between plants) = 16 meters.
Explanation
The problem phrasing implies that 13 meters is the required spacing unit per plant (as confirmed by the ground truth calculation 117/13=9). Adding the plant width (3m) to the spacing (13m) results in an incorrect unit size of 16m.
Answer Span:
3 meters (width of plant) + 13 meters (space between plants) = 16 meters
Reference/Question Span:
Haruka's flowers grow 3meters wide so she needs to leave 13 meters between every plant (including the plants width)
Question #205
Mr. Martinez sold his cottage for $690000. He paid the transfer fees that amounted to 3% of the selling price and also paid a brokerage fee that is 6% of the selling price. He also paid $590000 for th...
Clean
Full Question
Mr. Martinez sold his cottage for $690000. He paid the transfer fees that amounted to 3% of the selling price and also paid a brokerage fee that is 6% of the selling price. He also paid $590000 for the remaining loan amount on the cottage, and $5000 for closing costs. Mr. Martinez used the net proceeds from selling the cottage to invest in stocks. The stocks gained 10% each year for two years. How much were Mr. Martinez's net proceeds after two years?
Ground Truth Answer
Mr. Martinez paid $690000 x 3/100 = $20700 for the transfer fees. He paid $690000 x 6/100 = $41400 for the brokerage fee. So, Mr. Martinez paid a total of $20700 + $41400 + $590000 = $652100 for the transfer, brokerage, and loan fees. Hence, Mr. Martinez's net proceeds is $690000 - $652100 = $37900. Deducting the 5000 closing costs, we have $37900 - $5000 = 32900. We multiply 32900 by two 10% increments which would be 32900 * 110% * 110% = 39809 #### 39809
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Mr. Martinez sold his cottage for $690000. He paid the transfer fees that amounted to 3% of the selling price and also paid a brokerage fee that is 6% of the selling price. He also paid $590000 for the remaining loan amount on the cottage, and paid $5000 for closing costs. Mr. Martinez used the net proceeds from selling the cottage to invest in stocks. The stocks gained 10% each year for two years. How much were Mr. Martinez's net proceeds after two years? **Answer:** Mr. Martinez sold his cottage for $690000. The transfer fees were $690000 * 0.03 = $20700. The brokerage fee was $690000 * 0.06 = $41400. The total fees paid were $20700 + $41400 = $62100. The net proceeds from the sale, before paying off the loan and closing costs, were $690000 - $62100 = $627900. After paying off the loan and closing costs, the net proceeds were $627900 - $590000 - $5000 = $32900. After one year of investing, the net proceeds grew to $32900 * (1 + 0.10) = $36190. After two years of investing, the net proceeds grew to $36190 * (1 + 0.10) = $39809. Final Answer: \boxed{39809}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates all fees, determines the initial net proceeds, applies the two consecutive 10% gains correctly, and arrives at the correct final answer.

Arash weighs 200 lbs, and he has already consumed 1200 calories and burned 150 calories through exercise. Mei weighs 180 lbs, and she has already consumed 900 in food and 175 calories in ice cream. How many more grams of popcorn does Arash need to consume than Mei?
Ground Truth Answer
Arash's calorie target is 200 * 15 = 3000 calories. Arash needs 3000 - 1200 + 150 = 1950 calories more. That would be 1950 / 325 = 6 servings. Mei's calorie target is 180 * 15 = 2700 calories. Mei needs 2700 - 900 - 175 = 1625 calories more. That would be 1625 / 325 = 5 servings. Arash needs 6 - 5 = 1 more servings than Mei. Each serving is 100 / 4 = 25 gramss. Mei weighs 180 lbs, and she has already consumed 900 in food and 175 calories in ice cream. How many more grams of popcorn does Arash need to consume than Mei? Answer: Arash's target calorie intake is 200 lbs * 15 calories/lb = 3000 calories. His net calorie consumption so far is 1200 calories - 150 calories = 1050 calories. He needs to consume an additional 3000 calories - 1050 calories = 1950 calories. Mei's target calorie intake is 180 lbs * 15 calories/lb = 2700 calories. Her total calorie consumption so far is 900 calories + 175 calories = 1075 calories. She needs to consume an additional 2700 calories - 1075 calories = 1625 calories. A bag of popcorn has 325 calories/serving * 4 servings/100g bag = 1300 calories/100g bag. Arash needs to consume 1950 calories / 1300 calories/100g * 100g = 150g of popcorn. Mei needs to consume 1625 calories / 1300 calories/100g * 100g ‚âà 125g of popcorn. Arash needs to consume 150g - 125g = 25g more popcorn than Mei. Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{25}$

Theo weighs 250 lbs, and he has already consumed 1100 calories and burned 150 calories through exercise. Sakura weighs 130 lbs, and she has already consumed 900 in food and 175 calories in ice cream. How many more oz of cookies does Theo need to consume than Sakura?
Ground Truth Answer
Theo's calorie target is 250 * 15 = 3750 calories. Theo needs 3750 - 1100 + 150 = 2800 calories more. That would be 2800 / 175 = 16 servings. Sakura's calorie target is 130 * 15 = 1950 calories. Sakura needs 1950 - 900 - 175 = 875 calories more. That would be 875 / 175 = 5 servings. Theo needs 16 - 5 = 11 more servings than Sakura. Each serving is 125 / 5 = 25 ozs. So Theo needs 11 servings * 25 units/serving = 275 ozs more than Sakura. #### 275
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** According to its nutritional info, a bag of cookies has 175 calories per serving. A 125 oz bag has 5 servings. Sakura weighs 130 lbs, and she has already consumed 900 in food and 175 calories in ice cream. He has a net intake of 1100 calories - 150 calories = 950 calories. He can consume 3750 calories - 950 calories = 2800 calories more. Sakura's target calorie intake is 130 lbs * 15 calories/lb = 1950 calories. She has consumed 900 calories + 175 calories = 1075 calories. She can consume 1950 calories - 1075 calories = 875 calories more. One bag of cookies has 175 calories/serving * 5 servings = 875 calories. Since a bag is 125 oz, one ounce of cookies contains 875 calories / 125 oz = 7 calories/oz. Theo can consume 2800 calories / 7 calories/oz = 400 oz of cookies. Full Question
Dr. Miller sold his apartment for $490000. He paid the legal fees that amounted to 1% of the selling price and also paid a realtor fee that is 5% of the selling price. He also paid $390000 for the remaining loan amount on the apartment, and $10000 for closing costs. Dr. Miller used the net proceeds from selling the apartment to invest in stocks. The stocks gained 10% each year for two years. How much were Dr. Miller's net proceeds after two years?
Ground Truth Answer
Dr. Miller paid $490000 x 1/100 = $4900 for the legal fees. He paid $490000 x 5/100 = $24500 for the realtor fee. So, Dr. Miller paid a total of $4900 + $24500 + $390000 = $419400 for the legal, realtor, and loan fees. Hence, Dr. Miller's net proceeds is $490000 - $419400 = $70600. Deducting the 10000 closing costs, we have $70600 - $10000 = 60600. We multiply 60600 by two 10% increments which would be 60600 * 110% * 110% = 73326 #### 73326
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Dr. Miller sold his apartment for $490000. He paid the legal fees that amounted to 1% of the selling price and also paid a realtor fee that is 5% of the selling price. He also paid $390000 for the remaining loan amount on the apartment, and $10000 for closing costs. Dr. Miller used the net proceeds from selling the apartment to invest in stocks. The stocks gained 10% each year for two years. How much were Dr. Miller's net proceeds after two years? **Answer:** * Legal fees: $490000 * 0.01 = $4900 * Realtor fees: $490000 * 0.05 = $24500 * Total fees: $4900 + $24500 = $29400 * Net proceeds from sale (before investment): $490000 - $29400 - $390000 - $10000 = $60600 * Net proceeds after year 1: $60600 * (1 + 0.10) = $66660 * Net proceeds after year 2: $66660 * (1 + 0.10) = $73326 The answer is $\boxed{73326}$.

Question #209
Prof. Smith sold his house for $560000. He paid the registration fees that amounted to 3% of the selling price and also paid a agent fee that is 4% of the selling price. He also paid $440000 for the r...
Clean
Full Question
Prof. Smith sold his house for $560000. He paid the registration fees that amounted to 3% of the selling price and also paid a agent fee that is 4% of the selling price. He also paid $440000 for the remaining loan amount on the house, and $15000 for closing costs. Prof. Smith used the net proceeds from selling the house to invest in stocks. The stocks gained 10% each year for two years. How much were Prof. Smith's net proceeds after two years?
Ground Truth Answer
Prof. Smith paid $560000 x 3/100 = $16800 for the registration fees. He paid $560000 x 4/100 = $22400 for the agent fee. So, Prof. Smith paid a total of $16800 + $22400 + $440000 = $479200 for the registration, agent, and loan fees. Hence, Prof. Smith's net proceeds is $560000 - $479200 = $80800. Deducting the 15000 closing costs, we have $80800 - $15000 = 65800. We multiply 65800 by two 10% increments which would be 65800 * 110% * 110% = 79618 #### 79618
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Prof. Smith sold his house for $560000. He paid the registration fees that amounted to 3% of the selling price and also paid an agent fee that is 4% of the selling price. He also paid $440000 for the remaining loan amount on the house, and $15000 for closing costs. Prof. Smith used the net proceeds from selling the house to invest in stocks. The stocks gained 10% each year for two years. How much were Prof. Smith's net proceeds after two years? **Answer:** 1. **Calculate registration fees:** $560000 * 0.03 = $16800 2. **Calculate agent fees:** $560000 * 0.04 = $22400 3. **Calculate total expenses (excluding loan):** $16800 + $22400 + $15000 = $54200 4. **Calculate net proceeds from the sale (before investment):** $560000 - $54200 - $440000 = $65800 5. **Calculate the return after the first year:** $65800 * 0.10 = $6580 6. **Calculate the total amount after the first year:** $65800 + $6580 = $72380 7. **Calculate the return after the second year:** $72380 * 0.10 = $7238 8. **Calculate the total amount after the second year:** $72380 + $7238 = $79618 Therefore, Prof. Smith's net proceeds after two years were $\boxed{79618}$.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates all intermediate steps and arrives at the correct final answer. The calculation method for compounding interest (Steps 5-8) is mathematically sound and equivalent to the ground truth's method ($65800 * 1.10 * 1.10$). All arithmetic operations are correct.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #275
Zahra has a flower bed that is 144 feet long. Zahra wants to fill her flower bed with plants. Zahra's flowers grow 4feet wide so she needs to leave 12 feet between every plant (including the plants wi...
1 issue
Full Question
Zahra has a flower bed that is 144 feet long. Zahra wants to fill her flower bed with plants. Zahra's flowers grow 4feet wide so she needs to leave 12 feet between every plant (including the plants width). Zahra already owns 5 flowers. Each flowering plant costs ‚Ç£13 at the store. However, if she buys more than 2 plants, she'll receive a ‚Ç£5 discount on the entire purchase. How much money will Zahra spend at the store to fill up her flower bed?
Ground Truth Answer
Zahra's flower bed is 144 feet / 12 feet per plant = 12 plants needed. Zahra needs to buy 12 plants - 5 plants = 7 plants needed to purchase. Zahra will spend 7 plants * ‚Ç£13 = ‚Ç£91. Finally, we should reduce 5 as she has bought more than 2 plants: 91 - 5 = 86 #### 86
Generated Answer
Reformatted Question: Zahra has a flower bed that is 144 feet long. Zahra wants to fill her flower bed with plants. Zahra's flowers grow 4 feet wide so she needs to leave 12 feet between every plant (including the plants width). Zahra already owns 5 flowers. Each flowering plant costs ‚Ç£13 at the store. However, if she buys more than 2 plants, she'll receive a ‚Ç£5 discount on the entire purchase. How much money will Zahra spend at the store to fill up her flower bed? Answer: The total space each plant will occupy in the flower bed is the plant's width (4 feet) plus the required space between plants (12 feet), which totals 4 + 12 = 16 feet. The flower bed is 144 feet long, and each plant needs 16 feet of space. Therefore, the flower bed can hold 144 / 16 = 9 plants. Zahra already has 5 plants, so she needs to buy 9 - 5 = 4 plants from the store. Since Zahra is buying 4 plants, which is more than 2 plants, she gets a ‚Ç£5 discount. So, each plant will cost ‚Ç£13 - ‚Ç£5 = ‚Ç£8. The total cost of the 4 plants will be 4 * ‚Ç£8 = ‚Ç£32. Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{32}$
Overall Quality: poor
The reasoning chain contains two significant logical errors: misinterpreting the required spacing per plant and incorrectly applying the bulk purchase discount (per unit instead of total purchase).

Detected Issues (1)

logical_error high
Statement
Since Zahra is buying 4 plants, which is more than 2 plants, she gets a ‚Ç£5 discount. So, each plant will cost ‚Ç£13 - ‚Ç£5 = ‚Ç£8.
Explanation
The problem states the discount is on the 'entire purchase' if more than 2 plants are bought, not a per-plant reduction. The cost should be calculated based on the full price (4 * 13) and then the ‚Ç£5 discount subtracted from the total.
Answer Span:
each plant will cost ‚Ç£13 - ‚Ç£5 = ‚Ç£8
Reference/Question Span:
if she buys more than 2 plants, she'll receive a ‚Ç£5 discount on the entire purchase
Question #270
Kimia has a flower bed that is 126 feet long. Kimia wants to fill her flower bed with plants. Kimia's flowers grow 7feet wide so she needs to leave 14 feet between every plant (including the plants wi...
1 issue
Full Question
Kimia has a flower bed that is 126 feet long. Kimia wants to fill her flower bed with plants. Kimia's flowers grow 7feet wide so she needs to leave 14 feet between every plant (including the plants width). Kimia already owns 6 flowers. Each flowering plant costs ‚Ç£4 at the store. However, if she buys more than 2 plants, she'll receive a ‚Ç£5 discount on the entire purchase. How much money will Kimia spend at the store to fill up her flower bed?
Ground Truth Answer
Kimia's flower bed is 126 feet / 14 feet per plant = 9 plants needed. Kimia needs to buy 9 plants - 6 plants = 3 plants needed to purchase. Kimia will spend 3 plants * ‚Ç£4 = ‚Ç£12. Finally, we should reduce 5 as she has bought more than 2 plants: 12 - 5 = 7 #### 7
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Kimia has a flower bed that is 126 feet long. Kimia wants to fill her flower bed with plants. Kimia's flowers grow 7 feet wide, so she needs to leave 14 feet between every plant (including the plants width). Kimia already owns 6 flowers. Each flowering plant costs ‚Ç£4 at the store. However, if she buys more than 2 plants, she'll receive a ‚Ç£5 discount on the entire purchase. How much money will Kimia spend at the store to fill up her flower bed? **Answer:** 1. **Space needed per plant:** Each plant requires its width (7 feet) plus the space between plants (14 feet), totaling 21 feet. 2. **Number of plants that can fit:** The flower bed is 126 feet long, so a maximum of 126 feet / 21 feet/plant = 6 plants can fit. 3. **Number of plants to buy:** Kimia already has 6 flowers, and she can fit 6 plants in her flower bed. Therefore, she needs to buy 6 - 6 = 0 plants. 4. **Cost of plants:** Since Kimia doesn't need to buy any plants (0 plants), she will spend ‚Ç£0. The discount doesn't apply since she's buying less than 2 plants. Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{0}$
Overall Quality: poor
The reasoning chain contains a critical logical error in Step 1 regarding the interpretation of spacing requirements, leading to an incorrect calculation of the total number of plants needed and an incorrect final cost.

Detected Issues (1)

logical_error high
Statement
Each plant requires its width (7 feet) plus the space between plants (14 feet), totaling 21 feet.
Explanation
The problem implies that 14 feet is the total space allocated per plant placement (including the plant itself and the necessary gap), as 126 / 14 = 9 plants, which aligns with the expected result structure. Interpreting this as 7 feet (width) + 14 feet (gap) = 21 feet per plant leads to an incorrect total plant count (6 plants).
Answer Span:
Each plant requires its width (7 feet) plus the space between plants (14 feet), totaling 21 feet.
Reference/Question Span:
Kimia's flowers grow 7feet wide so she needs to leave 14 feet between every plant (including the plants width).
Question #272
Mei has a flower bed that is 120 meters long. Mei wants to fill her flower bed with plants. Mei's flowers grow 4meters wide so she needs to leave 12 meters between every plant (including the plants wi...
Clean
Full Question
Mei has a flower bed that is 120 meters long. Mei wants to fill her flower bed with plants. Mei's flowers grow 4meters wide so she needs to leave 12 meters between every plant (including the plants width). Mei already owns 6 flowers. Each flowering plant costs $5 at the store. However, if she buys more than 2 plants, she'll receive a $5 discount on the entire purchase. How much money will Mei spend at the store to fill up her flower bed?
Ground Truth Answer
Mei's flower bed is 120 meters / 12 meters per plant = 10 plants needed. Mei needs to buy 10 plants - 6 plants = 4 plants needed to purchase. Mei will spend 4 plants * $5 = $20. Finally, we should reduce 5 as she has bought more than 2 plants: 20 - 5 = 15 #### 15
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Mei has a flower bed that is 120 meters long. Mei wants to fill her flower bed with plants. Mei's flowers grow 4 meters wide so she needs to leave 12 meters between every plant (including the plants width). Mei already owns 6 flowers. Each flowering plant costs $5 at the store. However, if she buys more than 2 plants, she'll receive a $5 discount on the entire purchase. How much money will Mei spend at the store to fill up her flower bed? **Answer:** Each plant needs 4 meters + 12 meters = 16 meters of space. The flower bed is 120 meters long, so it can hold 120 meters / 16 meters/plant = 7.5 plants. Since she can't have half a plant, the flower bed can hold a maximum of 7 plants. Mei already has 6 flowers, so she needs 7 plants - 6 plants = 1 plant. Since Mei needs to buy 1 plant, which is not more than 2 plants, she won't receive the $5 discount. Therefore, Mei will spend 1 plant * $5/plant = $5. The answer is $\boxed{5}$.
Overall Quality: poor
The reasoning contains a critical logical error in interpreting the spacing requirement, leading to an incorrect calculation of the total number of plants needed and consequently an incorrect final cost.

Question #154
In Dr. Lee's class of 104 students, 50% of the class are volleyball players. Out of the remaining class, 25% of the students are robotics club members or part of choir members. These 3 groups of stude...
Clean
Full Question
In Dr. Lee's class of 104 students, 50% of the class are volleyball players. Out of the remaining class, 25% of the students are robotics club members or part of choir members. These 3 groups of students will need to leave early today to travel to an away competition. Half of the volleyball players are absent for being sick. Also, 3 cheerleaders will accompany each of these groups. How many students are leaving early to the competition?
Ground Truth Answer
50% of the 104 student class are volleyball players so that's 0.5*104 = 52 students. There are 104 students and 52 are volleyball players so that leaves 104-52 = 52 students 25% of the remaining 52 students are part of choir members or robotics club members so that's 0.25*52 = 13 students 52 students are volleyball players and 13 are part of choir members/robotics club members so 52+13 = 65 students will be leaving early. But half of volleyball players won't be able to attend so we reduce 52 / 2 = 26. Also 3 * 3 = 9 cheer leaders will join them. So we have 65 - 26 + 9 = 48 #### 48
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** In Dr. Lee's class of 104 students, 50% of the class are volleyball players. Out of the remaining class, 25% of the students are robotics club members or part of choir members. These 3 groups of students will need to leave early today to travel to an away competition. Half of the volleyball players are absent for being sick. Also, 3 cheerleaders will accompany each of these groups. How many students are leaving early to the competition? **Answer:** * **Volleyball players:** 104 students * 50% = 52 volleyball players. * **Volleyball players present:** 52 volleyball players * (1 - 50% sick) = 26 volleyball players present. * **Remaining students (not volleyball players):** 104 students - 52 volleyball players = 52 students. * **Robotics/Choir members:** 52 students * 25% = 13 robotics/choir members. * **Total students competing (excluding cheerleaders):** 26 volleyball players present + 13 robotics/choir members = 39 students competing. * **Cheerleaders:** 3 groups * 3 cheerleaders/group = 9 cheerleaders. * **Total students leaving early:** 39 students competing + 9 cheerleaders = 48 students. Final Answer: \boxed{48}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly follows all steps derived from the problem statement and performs all arithmetic calculations accurately. The final answer matches the ground truth.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #208
Dr. Smith sold his house for $590000. He paid the legal fees that amounted to 3% of the selling price and also paid a realtor fee that is 4% of the selling price. He also paid $380000 for the remainin...
Clean
Full Question
Dr. Smith sold his house for $590000. He paid the legal fees that amounted to 3% of the selling price and also paid a realtor fee that is 4% of the selling price. He also paid $380000 for the remaining loan amount on the house, and $25000 for closing costs. Dr. Smith used the net proceeds from selling the house to invest in stocks. The stocks gained 10% each year for two years. How much were Dr. Smith's net proceeds after two years?
Ground Truth Answer
Dr. Smith paid $590000 x 3/100 = $17700 for the legal fees. He paid $590000 x 4/100 = $23600 for the realtor fee. So, Dr. Smith paid a total of $17700 + $23600 + $380000 = $421300 for the legal, realtor, and loan fees. Hence, Dr. Smith's net proceeds is $590000 - $421300 = $168700. Deducting the 25000 closing costs, we have $168700 - $25000 = 143700. We multiply 143700 by two 10% increments which would be 143700 * 110% * 110% = 173877 #### 173877
Generated Answer
Reformatted Question: Dr. Smith sold his house for $590000. He paid the legal fees that amounted to 3% of the selling price and also paid a realtor fee that is 4% of the selling price. He also paid $380000 for the remaining loan amount on the house, and $25000 for closing costs. Dr. Smith used the net proceeds from selling the house to invest in stocks. The stocks gained 10% each year for two years. How much were Dr. Smith's net proceeds after two years? Answer: Legal fees: $590000 * 0.03 = $17700 Realtor fees: $590000 * 0.04 = $23600 Total fees and costs: $17700 + $23600 + $380000 + $25000 = $446300 Net proceeds from selling the house: $590000 - $446300 = $143700 Net proceeds after one year: $143700 * (1 + 0.10) = $158070 Net proceeds after two years: $158070 * (1 + 0.10) = $173877 Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{173877}$
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates all fees, determines the net proceeds, and applies the two consecutive 10% gains correctly, matching the ground truth.

Question #153
In Ms. Johnson's class of 20 students, 20% of the class are soccer players. Out of the remaining class, 50% of the students are debate team members or part of choir members. These 3 groups of students...
Clean
Full Question
In Ms. Johnson's class of 20 students, 20% of the class are soccer players. Out of the remaining class, 50% of the students are debate team members or part of choir members. These 3 groups of students will need to leave early today to travel to an away competition. Half of the soccer players are absent for being sick. Also, 3 cheerleaders will accompany each of these groups. How many students are leaving early to the competition?
Ground Truth Answer
20% of the 20 student class are soccer players so that's 0.2*20 = 4 students. There are 20 students and 4 are soccer players so that leaves 20-4 = 16 students 50% of the remaining 16 students are part of choir members or debate team members so that's 0.5*16 = 8 students 4 students are soccer players and 8 are part of choir members/debate team members so 4+8 = 12 students will be leaving early. But half of soccer players won't be able to attend so we reduce 4 / 2 = 2. Also 3 * 3 = 9 cheer leaders will join them. So we have 12 - 2 + 9 = 19 #### 19
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** In Ms. Johnson's class of 20 students, 20% of the class are soccer players. Out of the remaining class, 50% of the students are debate team members or part of choir members. These 3 groups of students will need to leave early today to travel to an away competition. Half of the soccer players are absent for being sick. Also, 3 cheerleaders will accompany each of these groups. How many students are leaving early to the competition? **Answer:** First, we find the number of soccer players: 20 students * 20% = 4 soccer players. Since half the soccer players are sick, only 4 soccer players / 2 = 2 soccer players are going to the competition. Next, we determine the number of remaining students: 20 students - 4 soccer players = 16 students. Then we find the number of debate/choir members: 16 remaining students * 50% = 8 debate/choir members. The number of students from the 3 groups going to the competition is: 2 soccer players + 8 debate/choir members = 10 students. Finally, we calculate the number of cheerleaders going: 3 groups * 3 cheerleaders/group = 9 cheerleaders. Therefore, the total number of students leaving early is 10 students + 9 cheerleaders = 19. The answer is $\boxed{19}$.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly follows all steps derived from the problem statement and performs all arithmetic calculations accurately. The final answer matches the ground truth.

Question #155

Clean
Full Question
In Mr. Smith's class of 80 students, 20% of the class are basketball players. Out of the remaining class, 50% of the students are dancers or part of debate team members. These 3 groups of students will need to leave early today to travel to an away tournament. Half of the basketball players are absent for being sick. Also, 3 cheerleaders will accompany each of these groups. How many students are leaving early to the tournament?
Ground Truth Answer
20% of the 80 student class are basketball players so that's 0.2*80 = 16 students. There are 80 students and 16 are basketball players so that leaves 80-16 = 64 students 50% of the remaining 64 students are part of debate team members or dancers so that's 0.5*64 = 32 students 16 students are basketball players and 32 are part of debate team members/dancers so 16+32 = 48 students will be leaving early. But half of basketball players won't be able to attend so we reduce 16 / 2 = 8. Also 3 * 3 = 9 cheer leaders will join them. So we have 48 - 8 + 9 = 49 #### 49
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** In Mr. Smith's class of 80 students, 20% of the class are basketball players. Out of the remaining class, 50% of the students are dancers or part of debate team members. These 3 groups of students will need to leave early today to travel to an away tournament. Half of the basketball players are absent for being sick. Also, 3 cheerleaders will accompany each of these groups. How many students are leaving early to the tournament? **Answer:** * There are a total of 80 students in Mr. Smith's class. * 20% of the class are basketball players, so there are 0.20 * 80 = 16 basketball players. * Half of the basketball players are sick, so 16/2 = 8 basketball players are going to the tournament. * The remaining students in the class are 80 - 16 = 64 students. * 50% of the remaining students are dancers or debate team members, so 0.50 * 64 = 32 dancers/debaters are going to the tournament. * There are 3 groups going to the tournament (basketball, dancers, debaters), and 3 cheerleaders will accompany each group, so there are 3 * 3 = 9 cheerleaders going to the tournament. * The total number of students leaving early is 8 + 32 + 9 = 49 students. Final Answer: \boxed{49}
Overall Quality: excellent

Question #150

Clean
Full Question
In Ms. Johnson's class of 100 students, 46% of the class are soccer players. Out of the remaining class, 50% of the students are robotics club members or part of dancers. These 3 groups of students will need to leave early today to travel to an away competition. Half of the soccer players are absent for being sick. Also, 3 cheerleaders will accompany each of these groups. How many students are leaving early to the competition?
Ground Truth Answer
46% of the 100 student class are soccer players so that's 0.46*100 = 46 students. There are 100 students and 46 are soccer players so that leaves 100-46 = 54 students 50% of the remaining 54 students are part of dancers or robotics club members so that's 0.5*54 = 27 students 46 students are soccer players and 27 are part of dancers/robotics club members so 46+27 = 73 students will be leaving early. But half of soccer players won't be able to attend so we reduce 46 / 2 = 23. Also 3 * 3 = 9 cheer leaders will join them. So we have 73 - 23 + 9 = 59 #### 59
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** In Ms. Johnson's class of 100 students, 46% of the class are soccer players. Out of the remaining class, 50% of the students are robotics club members or part of dancers. These 3 groups of students will need to leave early today to travel to an away competition. Half of the soccer players are absent for being sick. Also, 3 cheerleaders will accompany each of these groups. How many students are leaving early to the competition? **Answer:** * There are a total of 100 students in the class. * The number of soccer players is 46% of 100, which is 0.46 * 100 = 46 soccer players. * Half of the soccer players are absent, meaning 0.5 * 46 = 23 soccer players are absent. * The number of soccer players going to the competition is 46 - 23 = 23 soccer players. * The remaining students in the class are 100 - 46 = 54 students. * 50% of the remaining students are in robotics/dance, which is 0.5 * 54 = 27 robotics/dance students. * The total number of students from the three groups (soccer, robotics, dance) going to the competition is 23 + 27 = 50 students. * There are 3 cheerleaders for each of the 3 groups, so a total of 3 * 3 = 9 cheerleaders are also going. * The total number of people going to the competition is 50 students + 9 cheerleaders = 59 people. The total number of students leaving early for the competition is $\boxed{50}$. (Cheerleaders are not considered students in this final count).

Question #78
Sakura is an avid gardener. Two days ago, she received 49 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 7 potted plants on each of the 60 window ledges of her large country home. ...
Clean
Full Question
Sakura is an avid gardener. Two days ago, she received 49 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 7 potted plants on each of the 60 window ledges of her large country home. She also purchased 100 new plants yesterday at a 50% discount. Feeling generous, she has decided that she will give 3 potted plants from each ledge to friends and family tomorrow. How many potted plants will Sakura remain with?
Ground Truth Answer
Two days ago, before receiving the plants, Sakura had 60*7 = 420 potted plants After receiving an additional 49 plants, she therefore had a total of 420 + 49 = 469 potted plants. Adding the 100 new plants, it will be 469+100=569. Tomorrow, Sakura's plant giveaway will be 60*3 = 180 potted plants. She will therefore remain with 569 - 180 = 389 potted plants. #### 389
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Sakura is an avid gardener. Two days ago, she received 49 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 7 potted plants on each of the 60 window ledges of her large country home. She also purchased 100 new plants yesterday at a 50% discount. Feeling generous, she has decided that she will give 3 potted plants from each ledge to friends and family tomorrow. How many potted plants will Sakura remain with? **Answer:** 1. **Initial plants on ledges:** Sakura initially had 7 plants/ledge * 60 ledges = 420 plants on her window ledges. 2. **Total plants before gifts:** She received 49 new plants two days ago and 100 new plants yesterday. So, before giving any away, she had a total of 420 + 49 + 100 = 569 plants. 3. **Plants given away:** She will give away 3 plants/ledge * 60 ledges = 180 plants. 4. **Remaining plants:** After giving away the plants, she will have 569 - 180 = 389 plants remaining. Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{389}$
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly follows all steps required by the problem statement. All arithmetic calculations are accurate, and the logic correctly interprets the sequence of events (initial state, additions, subtractions).

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #79
Daphne is an avid gardener. Two days ago, she received 23 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 8 potted plants on each of the 56 window ledges of her large country home. ...
Clean
Full Question
Daphne is an avid gardener. Two days ago, she received 23 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 8 potted plants on each of the 56 window ledges of her large country home. She also purchased 200 new plants yesterday at a 50% discount. Feeling generous, she has decided that she will give 6 potted plants from each ledge to friends and family tomorrow. How many potted plants will Daphne remain with?
Ground Truth Answer
Two days ago, before receiving the plants, Daphne had 56*8 = 448 potted plants After receiving an additional 23 plants, she therefore had a total of 448 + 23 = 471 potted plants. Adding the 200 new plants, it will be 471+200=671. Tomorrow, Daphne's plant giveaway will be 56*6 = 336 potted plants. She will therefore remain with 671 - 336 = 335 potted plants. #### 335
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Daphne is an avid gardener. Two days ago, she received 23 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 8 potted plants on each of the 56 window ledges of her large country home. She also purchased 200 new plants yesterday at a 50% discount. Feeling generous, she has decided that she will give 6 potted plants from each ledge to friends and family tomorrow. How many potted plants will Daphne remain with? **Answer:** Daphne initially had 8 plants * 56 ledges = 448 plants on her window ledges. Two days ago, she received an additional 23 plants. Yesterday, she purchased another 200 plants. Her total number of plants before giving any away is 448 + 23 + 200 = 671 plants. She will give away 6 plants * 56 ledges = 336 plants. After giving away the plants, she will have 671 - 336 = 335 plants remaining. The answer is $\boxed{335}$.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly interprets the problem steps and performs all arithmetic calculations accurately, leading to the correct final answer.

Question #80
Amelia is an avid gardener. Last week, she received 25 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 12 potted plants on each of the 54 window ledges of her large country home. Sh...
Clean
Full Question
Amelia is an avid gardener. Last week, she received 25 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 12 potted plants on each of the 54 window ledges of her large country home. She also purchased 110 new plants yesterday at a 50% discount. Feeling generous, she has decided that she will give 4 potted plants from each ledge to friends and family tomorrow. How many potted plants will Amelia remain with?
Ground Truth Answer
Last week, before receiving the plants, Amelia had 54*12 = 648 potted plants After receiving an additional 25 plants, she therefore had a total of 648 + 25 = 673 potted plants. Adding the 110 new plants, it will be 673+110=783. Tomorrow, Amelia's plant giveaway will be 54*4 = 216 potted plants. She will therefore remain with 783 - 216 = 567 potted plants. #### 567
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Amelia is an avid gardener. Last week, she received 25 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 12 potted plants on each of the 54 window ledges of her large country home. She also purchased 110 new plants yesterday at a 50% discount. Feeling generous, she has decided that she will give 4 potted plants from each ledge to friends and family tomorrow. How many potted plants will Amelia remain with? **Answer:** 1. Amelia initially had 12 plants * 54 ledges = 648 plants on her window ledges. 2. She received 25 new plants last week, so her total became 648 + 25 = 673 plants. 3. She then purchased 110 new plants, increasing her total to 673 + 110 = 783 plants. 4. She will give away 4 plants * 54 ledges = 216 plants. 5. After giving away plants, she will have 783 - 216 = 567 plants remaining. The answer is $\boxed{567}$.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly follows all steps required by the problem statement. All arithmetic calculations are accurate, and the logic correctly incorporates the initial inventory, additions, and subtractions.

Question #81
Elena is an avid gardener. Two days ago, she received 38 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 12 potted plants on each of the 55 window ledges of her large country home. ...
Clean
Full Question
Elena is an avid gardener. Two days ago, she received 38 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 12 potted plants on each of the 55 window ledges of her large country home. She also purchased 70 new plants yesterday at a 50% discount. Feeling generous, she has decided that she will give 3 potted plants from each ledge to friends and family tomorrow. How many potted plants will Elena remain with?
Ground Truth Answer
Two days ago, before receiving the plants, Elena had 55*12 = 660 potted plants After receiving an additional 38 plants, she therefore had a total of 660 + 38 = 698 potted plants. Adding the 70 new plants, it will be 698+70=768. Tomorrow, Elena's plant giveaway will be 55*3 = 165 potted plants. She will therefore remain with 768 - 165 = 603 potted plants. #### 603
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Elena is an avid gardener. Two days ago, she received 38 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 12 potted plants on each of the 55 window ledges of her large country home. She also purchased 70 new plants yesterday at a 50% discount. Feeling generous, she has decided that she will give 3 potted plants from each ledge to friends and family tomorrow. How many potted plants will Elena remain with? **Answer:** 1. Elena initially had 12 plants/ledge * 55 ledges = 660 plants. 2. After receiving 38 new plants two days ago, she had 660 + 38 = 698 plants. 3. After purchasing 70 new plants yesterday, she had 698 + 70 = 768 plants. 4. She will give away 3 plants/ledge * 55 ledges = 165 plants. 5. Therefore, Elena will remain with 768 - 165 = 603 plants. The answer is $\boxed{603}$.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain is mathematically sound and logically follows all steps described in the problem. All calculations are correct.

Question #82
Yara is an avid gardener. Two days ago, she received 49 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 12 potted plants on each of the 54 window ledges of her large country home. S...
Clean
Full Question
Yara is an avid gardener. Two days ago, she received 49 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 12 potted plants on each of the 54 window ledges of her large country home. She also purchased 130 new plants yesterday at a 50% discount. Feeling generous, she has decided that she will give 4 potted plants from each ledge to friends and family tomorrow. How many potted plants will Yara remain with?
Ground Truth Answer
Two days ago, before receiving the plants, Yara had 54*12 = 648 potted plants After receiving an additional 49 plants, she therefore had a total of 648 + 49 = 697 potted plants. Adding the 130 new plants, it will be 697+130=827. Tomorrow, Yara's plant giveaway will be 54*4 = 216 potted plants. She will therefore remain with 827 - 216 = 611 potted plants. #### 611
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Yara is an avid gardener. Two days ago, she received 49 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 12 potted plants on each of the 54 window ledges of her large country home. She also purchased 130 new plants yesterday at a 50% discount. Feeling generous, she has decided that she will give 4 potted plants from each ledge to friends and family tomorrow. How many potted plants will Yara remain with? **Answer:** Yara initially had 12 plants/ledge * 54 ledges = 648 plants on her window ledges. With the 49 new plants from two days ago and the 130 new plants from yesterday, her total number of plants became 648 + 49 + 130 = 827 plants. She will give away 4 plants/ledge * 54 ledges = 216 plants tomorrow. Therefore, Yara will have 827 - 216 = 611 plants remaining. The answer is $\boxed{611}$.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain is mathematically sound and logically follows the steps required by the problem statement. All calculations are correct.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #97
Benjamin is selling cupcakes and pineapple pies for a fundraiser. On Wednesday, he sold 27 boxes of cupcake and 18 fewer boxes of pineapple pie, than on Thursday. On Thursday, he sold 12 more boxes of...
Clean
Full Question
Benjamin is selling cupcakes and pineapple pies for a fundraiser. On Wednesday, he sold 27 boxes of cupcake and 18 fewer boxes of pineapple pie, than on Thursday. On Thursday, he sold 12 more boxes of cupcakes than on Wednesday and 27 boxes of pineapple pie. On Friday, he sold as much as he did in the past two days combined. If the cupcake cost ¬•8 and the pineapple pie cost ¬•22, what was Benjamin's average daily earning?
Ground Truth Answer
He sold 27 + 12 = 39 boxes of cupcake on Thursday. The total number of boxes of cupcakes that Benjamin sold is 27 + 39 = 66. Benjamin earned 66 x ¬•8 = ¬•528 for selling cupcakes. He sold 27 - 18 = 9 boxes of pineapple pie on Wednesday. The total number of boxes of pineapple pie that Benjamin sold is 27 + 9 = 36. He earned 36 x ¬•22 = ¬•792 for selling pineapple pie. So, Benjamin earned ¬•528 + ¬•792 = ¬•1320 for two days. Finally, on Friday, he sold as much as he did in the past two days so 2 * 1320 = 2640. Finally, we should divide the total by 3 to get the average daily: 2640 / 3 = 880 #### 880
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Benjamin is selling cupcakes and pineapple pies for a fundraiser. On Wednesday, he sold 27 boxes of cupcake and 18 fewer boxes of pineapple pie, than on Thursday. On Thursday, he sold 12 more boxes of cupcakes than on Wednesday and 27 boxes of pineapple pie. On Friday, he sold as much as he did in the past two days combined. If the cupcake cost ¬•8 and the pineapple pie cost ¬•22, what was Benjamin's average daily earning? **Answer:** On Wednesday, Benjamin sold 27 boxes of cupcakes and 27 - 18 = 9 boxes of pineapple pie. On Thursday, Benjamin sold 27 + 12 = 39 boxes of cupcakes and 27 boxes of pineapple pie. On Friday, Benjamin sold 27 + 39 = 66 boxes of cupcakes and 9 + 27 = 36 boxes of pineapple pie. Wednesday's earnings: 27 * ¬•8 + 9 * ¬•22 = ¬•414 Thursday's earnings: 39 * ¬•8 + 27 * ¬•22 = ¬•906 Friday's earnings: 66 * ¬•8 + 36 * ¬•22 = ¬•1320 Total earnings: ¬•414 + ¬•906 + ¬•1320 = ¬•2640 Average daily earning: ¬•2640 / 3 = ¬•880 The answer is $\boxed{880}$.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly interprets the problem statement and performs all calculations accurately, leading to the correct final answer.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #112
Faisal went to buy some school supplies. He bought 18 pencils which cost ‚Ç£6.0 each, 14 rulers which cost ‚Ç£14.5 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ‚Ç£24. He also bought 5 colored pencils which cos...
Clean
Full Question
Faisal went to buy some school supplies. He bought 18 pencils which cost ‚Ç£6.0 each, 14 rulers which cost ‚Ç£14.5 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ‚Ç£24. He also bought 5 colored pencils which cost ‚Ç£9 each. Faisal can either pay a one-time ‚Ç£20 fee to become a member and get a 20% discount on all purchases, or not become a member and receive only a 5% discount. What is the least amount Faisal can spend on everything?
Ground Truth Answer
Faisal spent 18 x ‚Ç£6.0 = ‚Ç£108 for the pencils. He also spent 14 x ‚Ç£14.5 = ‚Ç£203 for the rulers. Therefore, Faisal spent a total of ‚Ç£108 + ‚Ç£203 + ‚Ç£24 = ‚Ç£335 for the school supplies. Finally we should include 5 * 9 = 45. The total will be be 380 If Faisal becomes a member he gets 20% discount, which will be ‚Ç£380 * 20% = ‚Ç£76 discount. He also has to pay ‚Ç£20 so it will be ‚Ç£76 - ‚Ç£20 = ‚Ç£56 cheaper. If Faisal doesn't become a member, get only gets 5% discount, which will be ‚Ç£380 * 5% = ‚Ç£19. Since ‚Ç£19 is smaller than ‚Ç£56, to pay the least, Faisal has to become member. So overall he pays ‚Ç£380 - ‚Ç£56 = ‚Ç£324 #### 324
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Faisal went to buy some school supplies. He bought 18 pencils which cost ‚Ç£6.0 each, 14 rulers which cost ‚Ç£14.5 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ‚Ç£24. He also bought 5 colored pencils which cost ‚Ç£9 each. Faisal can either pay a one-time ‚Ç£20 fee to become a member and get a 20% discount on all purchases, or not become a member and receive only a 5% discount. What is the least amount Faisal can spend on everything? **Answer:** Cost of pencils: 18 * ‚Ç£6 = ‚Ç£108 Cost of rulers: 14 * ‚Ç£14.5 = ‚Ç£203 Cost of bond paper: ‚Ç£24 Cost of colored pencils: 5 * ‚Ç£9 = ‚Ç£45 Total cost before discount: ‚Ç£108 + ‚Ç£203 + ‚Ç£24 + ‚Ç£45 = ‚Ç£380 **Option 1: Membership** Discount: ‚Ç£380 * 0.20 = ‚Ç£76 Cost after discount: ‚Ç£380 - ‚Ç£76 = ‚Ç£304 Total cost with membership fee: ‚Ç£304 + ‚Ç£20 = ‚Ç£324 **Option 2: No Membership** Discount: ‚Ç£380 * 0.05 = ‚Ç£19 Total cost without membership: ‚Ç£380 - ‚Ç£19 = ‚Ç£361 Comparing ‚Ç£324 and ‚Ç£361, the least amount Faisal can spend is ‚Ç£324. Final Answer: \boxed{324}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates the costs for all items, determines the total cost, and accurately evaluates both membership options (including the fee for Option 1) to find the minimum spending amount. All arithmetic operations are correct.

Question #159
A grandfather eats 10 sushi rolls per day, his partner eats 15 sushi rolls per day, and their son eats four-fifths of the combined number of sushi rolls they eat per day. After one month, the family d...
Clean
Full Question
A grandfather eats 10 sushi rolls per day, his partner eats 15 sushi rolls per day, and their son eats four-fifths of the combined number of sushi rolls they eat per day. After one month, the family decides to go on a diet in the second month, reducing their food consumption by 20% for the first half of the month, and then by an additional 25% for the second half. How many sushi rolls does this family eat in two months?
Ground Truth Answer
A grandfather and his partner consumption: 10 + 15 = 25 son consumes 4/5 more than A grandfather and his partner combined: 25 * 4/5 = 20. So son consumes 25 + 20 = 45 sushi rolls. During first month they consume 30 * 45 = 1350. The first half of the second month the consume 20% less each day: 80% * 45 = 36 . So in 15 days, they consume 540 sushi rolls. During second month, they consume 25% less than the first half each day, so they consume 75% * 36 = 27. So in 15 days, they consume 15 * 27 = 405 sushi rolls. In 2 months, they consume 45 + 540 + 405 = 2295 sushi rolls together. #### 2295
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** A grandfather eats 10 sushi rolls per day, his partner eats 15 sushi rolls per day, and their son eats four-fifths of the combined number of sushi rolls they eat per day. After one month, the family decides to go on a diet in the second month, reducing their food consumption by 20% for the first half of the month, and then by an additional 25% for the second half. How many sushi rolls does this family eat in two months? **Answer:** 1. **Combined consumption of grandfather and partner:** 10 + 15 = 25 sushi rolls per day 2. **Son's daily consumption:** 4/5 * 25 = 20 sushi rolls per day 3. **Total family consumption per day:** 25 + 20 = 45 sushi rolls per day 4. **First month's consumption (assuming 30 days):** 45 * 30 = 1350 sushi rolls 5. **Daily consumption in the first half of the second month (20% reduction):** 45 * (1 - 0.20) = 36 sushi rolls per day 6. **Consumption in the first half of the second month (assuming 15 days):** 36 * 15 = 540 sushi rolls 7. **Daily consumption in the second half of the second month (additional 25% reduction from the reduced amount):** 36 * (1 - 0.25) = 27 sushi rolls per day 8. **Consumption in the second half of the second month (assuming 15 days):** 27 * 15 = 405 sushi rolls 9. **Total consumption in the second month:** 540 + 405 = 945 sushi rolls 10. **Total consumption in two months (two months):** 1350 + 945 = 2295 sushi rolls Final Answer: \boxed{2295}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly interprets the problem steps and performs all arithmetic calculations accurately. The assumptions about month length (30 days total, 15 days per half) are standard for such problems and consistent with the ground truth derivation.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #151
In Ms. Johnson's class of 150 students, 40% of the class are soccer players. Out of the remaining class, 30% of the students are dancers or part of choir members. These 3 groups of students will need ...
Clean
Full Question
In Ms. Johnson's class of 150 students, 40% of the class are soccer players. Out of the remaining class, 30% of the students are dancers or part of choir members. These 3 groups of students will need to leave early today to travel to an away competition. Half of the soccer players are absent for being sick. Also, 3 cheerleaders will accompany each of these groups. How many students are leaving early to the competition?
Ground Truth Answer
40% of the 150 student class are soccer players so that's 0.4*150 = 60 students. There are 150 students and 60 are soccer players so that leaves 150-60 = 90 students 30% of the remaining 90 students are part of choir members or dancers so that's 0.3*90 = 27 students 60 students are soccer players and 27 are part of choir members/dancers so 60+27 = 87 students will be leaving early. But half of soccer players won't be able to attend so we reduce 60 / 2 = 30. Also 3 * 3 = 9 cheer leaders will join them. So we have 87 - 30 + 9 = 66 #### 66
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** In Ms. Johnson's class of 150 students, 40% of the class are soccer players. Out of the remaining class, 30% of the students are dancers or part of choir members. These 3 groups of students will need to leave early today to travel to an away competition. Half of the soccer players are absent for being sick. Also, 3 cheerleaders will accompany each of these groups. How many students are leaving early to the competition? **Answer:** * **Soccer Players:** 150 students * 40% = 60 soccer players. * **Sick Soccer Players:** 60 soccer players * 50% = 30 sick soccer players. * **Soccer Players Going to Competition:** 60 soccer players - 30 sick soccer players = 30 soccer players. * **Remaining Students (excluding soccer players):** 150 students - 60 soccer players = 90 students. * **Dancers/Choir Members:** 90 students * 30% = 27 dancers/choir members. * **Total Students from the 3 groups going (excluding cheerleaders):** 30 + 27 = 57 students * **Cheerleaders:** 3 groups * 3 cheerleaders/group = 9 cheerleaders. * **Total Students Leaving Early:** 57 students + 9 cheerleaders = 66. Final Answer: \boxed{66}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly follows all steps derived from the problem statement and performs all calculations accurately, leading to the correct final answer.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #212
Benjamin is raising money for a 3-day science fair. Each day costs ‚Ç∫250 for hotel, ‚Ç∫30 for food, and ‚Ç∫20 for transportation. Benjamin only has ‚Ç∫165. His friends have chipped in and will cover the cost...
Clean
Full Question
Benjamin is raising money for a 3-day science fair. Each day costs ‚Ç∫250 for hotel, ‚Ç∫30 for food, and ‚Ç∫20 for transportation. Benjamin only has ‚Ç∫165. His friends have chipped in and will cover the cost of all the food for the science fair. Benjamin has also applied for help from the parent association, which has decided to cover a tenth of the remaining cost of the science fair. How much money is Benjamin still missing?
Ground Truth Answer
Total cost of science fair for one day: ‚Ç∫250 + ‚Ç∫20 + ‚Ç∫30 = ‚Ç∫300. For 3 days, the cost will be 3 * ‚Ç∫300 = ‚Ç∫900. Benjamin's friends will cover the cost of food which will be 3 * ‚Ç∫30 = ‚Ç∫90. So the remaining cost is 900 - 90 = ‚Ç∫810. parent association is going to pay 1/10 of the remaining cost which will be 1/10 * ‚Ç∫810 = ‚Ç∫81. So he still needs ‚Ç∫810-‚Ç∫81 = ‚Ç∫729. Benjamin also has ‚Ç∫165 so he needs ‚Ç∫729 - ‚Ç∫165 = ‚Ç∫564. #### 564
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Benjamin is raising money for a 3-day science fair. Each day costs ‚Ç∫250 for hotel, ‚Ç∫30 for food, and ‚Ç∫20 for transportation. Benjamin only has ‚Ç∫165. His friends have chipped in and will cover the cost of all the food for the science fair. Benjamin has also applied for help from the parent association, which has decided to cover a tenth of the remaining cost of the science fair. How much money is Benjamin still missing? **Answer:** The total cost for the hotel for 3 days is 3 * ‚Ç∫250 = ‚Ç∫750. The total cost for food for 3 days is 3 * ‚Ç∫30 = ‚Ç∫90. The total cost for transportation for 3 days is 3 * ‚Ç∫20 = ‚Ç∫60. Since the friends are covering the ‚Ç∫90 food cost (), we only need to account for the hotel (‚Ç∫750) and transportation (‚Ç∫60). The combined cost of hotel and transportation is ‚Ç∫750 + ‚Ç∫60 = ‚Ç∫810. The parent association will cover a tenth of this remaining cost, which is (1/10) * ‚Ç∫810 = ‚Ç∫81. This means Benjamin needs to cover ‚Ç∫810 - ‚Ç∫81 = ‚Ç∫729. Benjamin currently has ‚Ç∫165. Therefore, Benjamin is still missing ‚Ç∫729 - ‚Ç∫165 = ‚Ç∫564. Final Answer: \boxed{564}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates the total cost, accounts for the food cost covered by friends, calculates the remaining cost, applies the parent association's contribution (1/10 of the remaining cost), and finally subtracts Benjamin's existing funds to find the amount still missing. All arithmetic operations are correct.
