Question #83
Mei is an avid gardener. Two days ago, she received 38 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 9 potted plants on each of the 60 window ledges of her large country home. She...
Clean
Full Question
Mei is an avid gardener. Two days ago, she received 38 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 9 potted plants on each of the 60 window ledges of her large country home. She also purchased 170 new plants yesterday at a 50% discount. Feeling generous, she has decided that she will give 6 potted plants from each ledge to friends and family tomorrow. How many potted plants will Mei remain with?
Ground Truth Answer
Two days ago, before receiving the plants, Mei had 60*9 = 540 potted plants After receiving an additional 38 plants, she therefore had a total of 540 + 38 = 578 potted plants. Adding the 170 new plants, it will be 578+170=748. Tomorrow, Mei's plant giveaway will be 60*6 = 360 potted plants. She will therefore remain with 748 - 360 = 388 potted plants. #### 388
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Mei is an avid gardener. Two days ago, she received 38 new potted plants from her favorite plant nursery. She already has 9 potted plants on each of the 60 window ledges of her large country home. She also purchased 170 new plants yesterday at a 50% discount. Feeling generous, she has decided that she will give 6 potted plants from each ledge to friends and family tomorrow. How many potted plants will Mei remain with? **Answer:** 1. Mei started with 9 plants * 60 ledges = 540 plants. 2. Two days ago, she received 38 new plants, so she had 540 + 38 = 578 plants. 3. Yesterday, she purchased an additional 170 new plants, bringing her total to 578 + 170 = 748 plants. 4. Tomorrow, she will give away 6 plants * 60 ledges = 360 plants. 5. After giving away the plants, she will have 748 - 360 = 388 plants remaining. The answer is $\boxed{388}$.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain is mathematically sound and logically follows the steps required by the problem statement. All calculations are correct.

Question #110
Deshawn went to buy some school supplies. He bought 14 erasers which cost ‚Ç∫7.5 each, 4 rulers which cost ‚Ç∫18.5 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ‚Ç∫21. He also bought 8 folders which cost ‚Ç∫10 ea...
Clean
Full Question
Deshawn went to buy some school supplies. He bought 14 erasers which cost ‚Ç∫7.5 each, 4 rulers which cost ‚Ç∫18.5 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ‚Ç∫21. He also bought 8 folders which cost ‚Ç∫10 each. Deshawn can either pay a one-time ‚Ç∫20 fee to become a member and get a 20% discount on all purchases, or not become a member and receive only a 5% discount. What is the least amount DeShawn can spend on everything?
Ground Truth Answer
DeShawn spent 14 x ‚Ç∫7.5 = ‚Ç∫105 for the erasers. He also spent 4 x ‚Ç∫18.5 = ‚Ç∫74 for the rulers. Therefore, DeShawn spent a total of ‚Ç∫105 + ‚Ç∫74 + ‚Ç∫21 = ‚Ç∫200 for the school supplies. Finally we should include 8 * 10 = 80. The total will be be 280 If DeShawn becomes a member he gets 20% discount, which will be ‚Ç∫280 * 20% = ‚Ç∫56 discount. He also has to pay ‚Ç∫20 so it will be ‚Ç∫56 - ‚Ç∫20 = ‚Ç∫36 cheaper. If DeShawn doesn't become a member, get only gets 5% discount, which will be ‚Ç∫280 * 5% = ‚Ç∫14. Since ‚Ç∫14 is smaller than ‚Ç∫36, to pay the least, DeShawn has to become member. So overall he pays ‚Ç∫280 - ‚Ç∫36 = ‚Ç∫244 #### 244
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Deshawn went to buy some school supplies. He bought 14 erasers which cost ‚Ç∫7.5 each, 4 rulers which cost ‚Ç∫18.5 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ‚Ç∫21. He also bought 8 folders which cost ‚Ç∫10 each. Deshawn can either pay a one-time ‚Ç∫20 fee to become a member and get a 20% discount on all purchases, or not become a member and receive only a 5% discount. What is the least amount DeShawn can spend on everything? **Answer:** Cost of erasers: 14 * ‚Ç∫7.5 = ‚Ç∫105 Cost of rulers: 4 * ‚Ç∫18.5 = ‚Ç∫74 Cost of bond paper: ‚Ç∫21 Cost of folders: 8 * ‚Ç∫10 = ‚Ç∫80 Total cost before discount: ‚Ç∫105 + ‚Ç∫74 + ‚Ç∫21 + ‚Ç∫80 = ‚Ç∫280 Option 1: Membership with 20% discount Discount amount: ‚Ç∫280 * 0.20 = ‚Ç∫56 Cost after discount: ‚Ç∫280 - ‚Ç∫56 = ‚Ç∫224 Final cost with membership fee: ‚Ç∫224 + ‚Ç∫20 = ‚Ç∫244 Option 2: No membership with 5% discount Discount amount: ‚Ç∫280 * 0.05 = ‚Ç∫14 Final cost without membership: ‚Ç∫280 - ‚Ç∫14 = ‚Ç∫266 Comparing the final costs, ‚Ç∫244 (with membership) is less than ‚Ç∫266 (without membership). Final Answer: The least amount Deshawn can spend is \boxed{244}.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates the total cost before discounts, evaluates both membership options (including the fee for Option 1), and correctly determines the minimum cost.

Question #157
An uncle eats 24 hamburgers per day, his spouse eats 24 hamburgers per day, and their grandchild eats one-half of the combined number of hamburgers they eat per day. After one month, the family decide...
Clean
Full Question
An uncle eats 24 hamburgers per day, his spouse eats 24 hamburgers per day, and their grandchild eats one-half of the combined number of hamburgers they eat per day. After one month, the family decides to go on a diet in the second month, reducing their food consumption by 75% for the first half of the month, and then by an additional 50% for the second half. How many hamburgers does this family eat in two months?
Ground Truth Answer
An uncle and his spouse consumption: 24 + 24 = 48 grandchild consumes 1/2 more than An uncle and his spouse combined: 48 * 1/2 = 24. So grandchild consumes 48 + 24 = 72 hamburgers. During first month they consume 30 * 72 = 2160. The first half of the second month the consume 75% less each day: 25% * 72 = 18 . So in 15 days, they consume 270 hamburgers. During second month, they consume 50% less than the first half each day, so they consume 50% * 18 = 9. So in 15 days, they consume 15 * 9 = 135 hamburgers. In 2 months, they consume 72 + 270 + 135 = 2565 hamburgers together. #### 2565
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** An uncle eats 24 hamburgers per day, his spouse eats 24 hamburgers per day, and their grandchild eats one-half of the combined number of hamburgers they eat per day. After one month, the family decides to go on a diet in the second month, reducing their food consumption by 75% for the first half of the month, and then by an additional 50% for the second half. How many hamburgers does this family eat in two months? **Answer:** First, let's calculate the daily hamburger consumption of the grandchild: (24 + 24) / 2 = 24 hamburgers per day. The family's total daily hamburger consumption is: 24 + 24 + 24 = 72 hamburgers per day. Assuming a 30-day month, the family eats 72 * 30 = 2160 hamburgers in the first month. In the first half of the second month (15 days), they reduce consumption by 75%, so they eat 25% of their usual amount: 72 * 0.25 = 18 hamburgers per day. Over 15 days, this totals 18 * 15 = 270 hamburgers. In the second half of the second month (15 days), they further reduce consumption by 50% from their already reduced amount. This means they eat 50% of 18 hamburgers per day: 18 * 0.5 = 9 hamburgers per day. Over 15 days, this is 9 * 15 = 135 hamburgers. The total hamburger consumption for the second month is 270 + 135 = 405 hamburgers. The total hamburger consumption over two months is 2160 + 405 = 2565 hamburgers. Final Answer: \boxed{2565}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain is mathematically sound and internally consistent based on a plausible interpretation of the ambiguous prompt regarding the grandchild's consumption. The final result matches the ground truth.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #109
Bodhi went to buy some school supplies. He bought 24 folders which cost ‚Ç¨2.75 each, 12 pencils which cost ‚Ç¨19.25 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ‚Ç¨23. He also bought 5 markers which cost ‚Ç¨8 e...
Clean
Full Question
Bodhi went to buy some school supplies. He bought 24 folders which cost ‚Ç¨2.75 each, 12 pencils which cost ‚Ç¨19.25 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ‚Ç¨23. He also bought 5 markers which cost ‚Ç¨8 each. Bodhi can either pay a one-time ‚Ç¨20 fee to become a member and get a 20% discount on all purchases, or not become a member and receive only a 5% discount. What is the least amount Bodhi can spend on everything?
Ground Truth Answer
Bodhi spent 24 x ‚Ç¨2.75 = ‚Ç¨66 for the folders. He also spent 12 x ‚Ç¨19.25 = ‚Ç¨231 for the pencils. Therefore, Bodhi spent a total of ‚Ç¨66 + ‚Ç¨231 + ‚Ç¨23 = ‚Ç¨320 for the school supplies. Finally we should include 5 * 8 = 40. The total will be be 360 If Bodhi becomes a member he gets 20% discount, which will be ‚Ç¨360 * 20% = ‚Ç¨72 discount. He also has to pay ‚Ç¨20 so it will be ‚Ç¨72 - ‚Ç¨20 = ‚Ç¨52 cheaper. If Bodhi doesn't become a member, get only gets 5% discount, which will be ‚Ç¨360 * 5% = ‚Ç¨18. Since ‚Ç¨18 is smaller than ‚Ç¨52, to pay the least, Bodhi has to become member. So overall he pays ‚Ç¨360 - ‚Ç¨52 = ‚Ç¨308 #### 308
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Bodhi went to buy some school supplies. He bought 24 folders which cost ‚Ç¨2.75 each, 12 pencils which cost ‚Ç¨19.25 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ‚Ç¨23. He also bought 5 markers which cost ‚Ç¨8 each. Bodhi can either pay a one-time ‚Ç¨20 fee to become a member and get a 20% discount on all purchases, or not become a member and receive only a 5% discount. What is the least amount Bodhi can spend on everything? **Answer:** Cost of folders: 24 * ‚Ç¨2.75 = ‚Ç¨66 Cost of pencils: 12 * ‚Ç¨19.25 = ‚Ç¨231 Cost of bond paper: ‚Ç¨23 Cost of markers: 5 * ‚Ç¨8 = ‚Ç¨40 Total cost before discount: ‚Ç¨66 + ‚Ç¨231 + ‚Ç¨23 + ‚Ç¨40 = ‚Ç¨360 Scenario 1: 5% discount (no membership) Discount amount: ‚Ç¨360 * 0.05 = ‚Ç¨18 Final cost: ‚Ç¨360 - ‚Ç¨18 = ‚Ç¨342 Scenario 2: 20% discount with ‚Ç¨20 membership fee Discount amount: ‚Ç¨360 * 0.20 = ‚Ç¨72 Cost after discount: ‚Ç¨360 - ‚Ç¨72 = ‚Ç¨288 Final cost (including membership): ‚Ç¨288 + ‚Ç¨20 = ‚Ç¨308 Comparing the final costs of both scenarios, ‚Ç¨342 (no membership) and ‚Ç¨308 (with membership), the least amount Bodhi can spend is ‚Ç¨308. Final Answer: \boxed{308}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates the costs for all items, determines the total cost, and accurately evaluates both scenarios (with and without membership) to find the minimum spending amount. All arithmetic operations are correct.

Question #161
A father eats 25 hamburgers per day, his wife eats 20 hamburgers per day, and their daughter eats two-thirds of the combined number of hamburgers they eat per day. After one month, the family decides ...
Clean
Full Question
A father eats 25 hamburgers per day, his wife eats 20 hamburgers per day, and their daughter eats two-thirds of the combined number of hamburgers they eat per day. After one month, the family decides to go on a diet in the second month, reducing their food consumption by 20% for the first half of the month, and then by an additional 25% for the second half. How many hamburgers does this family eat in two months?
Ground Truth Answer
A father and his wife consumption: 25 + 20 = 45 daughter consumes 2/3 more than A father and his wife combined: 45 * 2/3 = 30. So daughter consumes 45 + 30 = 75 hamburgers. During first month they consume 30 * 75 = 2250. The first half of the second month the consume 20% less each day: 80% * 75 = 60 . So in 15 days, they consume 900 hamburgers. During second month, they consume 25% less than the first half each day, so they consume 75% * 60 = 45. So in 15 days, they consume 15 * 45 = 675 hamburgers. In 2 months, they consume 75 + 900 + 675 = 3825 hamburgers together. #### 3825
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** A father eats 25 hamburgers per day, his wife eats 20 hamburgers per day, and their daughter eats two-thirds of the combined number of hamburgers they eat per day. After one month, the family decides to go on a diet in the second month, reducing their food consumption by 20% for the first half of the month, and then by an additional 25% for the second half. How many hamburgers does this family eat in two months? **Answer:** 1. **Combined consumption of father and wife:** 25 + 20 = 45 hamburgers/day 2. **Daughter's consumption:** 2/3 * 45 = 30 hamburgers/day 3. **Total family consumption per day:** 45 + 30 = 75 hamburgers/day 4. **Consumption in the first month (assuming 30 days):** 75 hamburgers/day * 30 days = 2250 hamburgers 5. **Consumption during the first half of the second month:** 75 hamburgers/day * (1 - 0.20) * 15 days = 900 hamburgers 6. **Consumption during the second half of the second month:** 75 hamburgers/day * (1 - 0.20) * (1 - 0.25) * 15 days = 675 hamburgers 7. **Total consumption in the second month:** 900 + 675 = 1575 hamburgers 8. **Total consumption in two months:** 2250 + 1575 = 3825 hamburgers Final Answer: \boxed{3825}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly interprets the problem and performs all calculations accurately, leading to the correct final answer.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #152
In Mrs. Garcia's class of 160 students, 50% of the class are swimmers. Out of the remaining class, 35% of the students are debate team members or part of dancers. These 3 groups of students will need ...
Clean
Full Question
In Mrs. Garcia's class of 160 students, 50% of the class are swimmers. Out of the remaining class, 35% of the students are debate team members or part of dancers. These 3 groups of students will need to leave early today to travel to an away tournament. Half of the swimmers are absent for being sick. Also, 3 cheerleaders will accompany each of these groups. How many students are leaving early to the tournament?
Ground Truth Answer
50% of the 160 student class are swimmers so that's 0.5*160 = 80 students. There are 160 students and 80 are swimmers so that leaves 160-80 = 80 students 35% of the remaining 80 students are part of dancers or debate team members so that's 0.35*80 = 28 students 80 students are swimmers and 28 are part of dancers/debate team members so 80+28 = 108 students will be leaving early. But half of swimmers won't be able to attend so we reduce 80 / 2 = 40. Also 3 * 3 = 9 cheer leaders will join them. So we have 108 - 40 + 9 = 77 #### 77
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** In Mrs. Garcia's class of 160 students, 50% of the class are swimmers. Out of the remaining class, 35% of the students are debate team members or part of dancers. These 3 groups of students will need to leave early today to travel to an away tournament. Half of the swimmers are absent for being sick. Also, 3 cheerleaders will accompany each of these groups. How many students are leaving early to the tournament? **Answer:** * The total number of students in Mrs. Garcia's class is 160. * The number of swimmers is 50% of 160, which is (50/100) * 160 = 80 students. * Since half of the swimmers are absent, the number of swimmers going to the tournament is 80 / 2 = 40 students. * The remaining class consists of 160 - 80 = 80 students. * 35% of the remaining class are debaters or dancers. This is (35/100) * 80 = 28 students. * Three groups are going: swimmers, debaters/dancers, and cheerleaders. * There are 3 cheerleaders per group, so a total of 3 * 3 = 9 cheerleaders are going. * The total number of students leaving early for the tournament is 40 swimmers + 28 debaters/dancers + 9 cheerleaders = 77 students. Final Answer: \boxed{77}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly follows all steps derived from the problem statement and performs all calculations accurately. The final answer matches the ground truth.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #113
Oscar went to buy some school supplies. He bought 24 notebooks which cost ‚Ç∫3.5 each, 6 rulers which cost ‚Ç∫13.0 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ‚Ç∫15. He also bought 7 pencils which cost ‚Ç∫9 eac...
Clean
Full Question
Oscar went to buy some school supplies. He bought 24 notebooks which cost ‚Ç∫3.5 each, 6 rulers which cost ‚Ç∫13.0 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ‚Ç∫15. He also bought 7 pencils which cost ‚Ç∫9 each. Oscar can either pay a one-time ‚Ç∫20 fee to become a member and get a 20% discount on all purchases, or not become a member and receive only a 5% discount. What is the least amount Oscar can spend on everything?
Ground Truth Answer
Oscar spent 24 x ‚Ç∫3.5 = ‚Ç∫84 for the notebooks. He also spent 6 x ‚Ç∫13.0 = ‚Ç∫78 for the rulers. Therefore, Oscar spent a total of ‚Ç∫84 + ‚Ç∫78 + ‚Ç∫15 = ‚Ç∫177 for the school supplies. Finally we should include 7 * 9 = 63. The total will be be 240 If Oscar becomes a member he gets 20% discount, which will be ‚Ç∫240 * 20% = ‚Ç∫48 discount. He also has to pay ‚Ç∫20 so it will be ‚Ç∫48 - ‚Ç∫20 = ‚Ç∫28 cheaper. If Oscar doesn't become a member, get only gets 5% discount, which will be ‚Ç∫240 * 5% = ‚Ç∫12. Since ‚Ç∫12 is smaller than ‚Ç∫28, to pay the least, Oscar has to become member. So overall he pays ‚Ç∫240 - ‚Ç∫28 = ‚Ç∫212 #### 212
Generated Answer
Reformatted Question: Oscar went to buy some school supplies. He bought 24 notebooks which cost ‚Ç∫3.5 each, 6 rulers which cost ‚Ç∫13.0 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ‚Ç∫15. He also bought 7 pencils which cost ‚Ç∫9 each. Oscar can either pay a one-time ‚Ç∫20 fee to become a member and get a 20% discount on all purchases, or not become a member and receive only a 5% discount. What is the least amount Oscar can spend on everything? Answer: Cost of notebooks: 24 * ‚Ç∫3.5 = ‚Ç∫84 Cost of rulers: 6 * ‚Ç∫13.0 = ‚Ç∫78 Cost of bond paper: ‚Ç∫15 Cost of pencils: 7 * ‚Ç∫9 = ‚Ç∫63 Total cost before discount: ‚Ç∫84 + ‚Ç∫78 + ‚Ç∫15 + ‚Ç∫63 = ‚Ç∫240 Option 1: Member with 20% discount Discount amount: ‚Ç∫240 * 0.20 = ‚Ç∫48 Cost after discount: ‚Ç∫240 - ‚Ç∫48 = ‚Ç∫192 Total cost with membership fee: ‚Ç∫192 + ‚Ç∫20 = ‚Ç∫212 Option 2: Non-member with 5% discount Discount amount: ‚Ç∫240 * 0.05 = ‚Ç∫12 Total cost: ‚Ç∫240 - ‚Ç∫12 = ‚Ç∫228 Comparing ‚Ç∫212 (member) and ‚Ç∫228 (non-member), the least amount Oscar can spend is ‚Ç∫212. Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{212}$
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates the costs for all items, determines the total cost, accurately calculates the costs for both membership options (including the fee for Option 1), and correctly identifies the minimum cost.

Question #108
Leon went to buy some school supplies. He bought 8 crayons which cost ¬•7.0 each, 8 notebooks which cost ¬•13.75 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ¬•10. He also bought 4 folders which cost ¬•11 ea...
Clean
Full Question
Leon went to buy some school supplies. He bought 8 crayons which cost ¬•7.0 each, 8 notebooks which cost ¬•13.75 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ¬•10. He also bought 4 folders which cost ¬•11 each. Leon can either pay a one-time ¬•20 fee to become a member and get a 20% discount on all purchases, or not become a member and receive only a 5% discount. What is the least amount Leon can spend on everything?
Ground Truth Answer
Leon spent 8 x ¬•7.0 = ¬•56 for the crayons. He also spent 8 x ¬•13.75 = ¬•110 for the notebooks. Therefore, Leon spent a total of ¬•56 + ¬•110 + ¬•10 = ¬•176 for the school supplies. Finally we should include 4 * 11 = 44. The total will be be 220 If Leon becomes a member he gets 20% discount, which will be ¬•220 * 20% = ¬•44 discount. He also has to pay ¬•20 so it will be ¬•44 - ¬•20 = ¬•24 cheaper. If Leon doesn't become a member, get only gets 5% discount, which will be ¬•220 * 5% = ¬•11. Since ¬•11 is smaller than ¬•24, to pay the least, Leon has to become member. So overall he pays ¬•220 - ¬•24 = ¬•196 #### 196
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Leon went to buy some school supplies. He bought 8 crayons which cost ¬•7.0 each, 8 notebooks which cost ¬•13.75 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ¬•10. He also bought 4 folders which cost ¬•11 each. Leon can either pay a one-time ¬•20 fee to become a member and get a 20% discount on all purchases, or not become a member and receive only a 5% discount. What is the least amount Leon can spend on everything? **Answer:** Cost of crayons: 8 * ¬•7.0 = ¬•56 Cost of notebooks: 8 * ¬•13.75 = ¬•110 Cost of bond paper: ¬•10 Cost of folders: 4 * ¬•11 = ¬•44 Total cost before discount: ¬•56 + ¬•110 + ¬•10 + ¬•44 = ¬•220 Option 1: Member with 20% discount Discount amount: ¬•220 * 0.20 = ¬•44 Cost after discount: ¬•220 - ¬•44 = ¬•176 Final cost (including membership fee): ¬•176 + ¬•20 = ¬•196 Option 2: Non-member with 5% discount Discount amount: ¬•220 * 0.05 = ¬•11 Final cost: ¬•220 - ¬•11 = ¬•209 Comparing ¬•196 and ¬•209, the least amount Leon can spend is ¬•196. Final Answer: \boxed{196}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates the costs for all items, determines the total cost, and accurately evaluates both membership options (Option 1: ¬•196, Option 2: ¬•209). The final conclusion that ¬•196 is the least amount is logically sound based on the calculations.

Question #111
Andre went to buy some school supplies. He bought 20 markers which cost ‚Ç£8.0 each, 10 pencils which cost ‚Ç£18.0 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ‚Ç£15. He also bought 5 rulers which cost ‚Ç£9 each...
Clean
Full Question
Andre went to buy some school supplies. He bought 20 markers which cost ‚Ç£8.0 each, 10 pencils which cost ‚Ç£18.0 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ‚Ç£15. He also bought 5 rulers which cost ‚Ç£9 each. Andre can either pay a one-time ‚Ç£20 fee to become a member and get a 20% discount on all purchases, or not become a member and receive only a 5% discount. What is the least amount Andre can spend on everything?
Ground Truth Answer
Andre spent 20 x ‚Ç£8.0 = ‚Ç£160 for the markers. He also spent 10 x ‚Ç£18.0 = ‚Ç£180 for the pencils. Therefore, Andre spent a total of ‚Ç£160 + ‚Ç£180 + ‚Ç£15 = ‚Ç£355 for the school supplies. Finally we should include 5 * 9 = 45. The total will be be 400 If Andre becomes a member he gets 20% discount, which will be ‚Ç£400 * 20% = ‚Ç£80 discount. He also has to pay ‚Ç£20 so it will be ‚Ç£80 - ‚Ç£20 = ‚Ç£60 cheaper. If Andre doesn't become a member, get only gets 5% discount, which will be ‚Ç£400 * 5% = ‚Ç£20. Since ‚Ç£20 is smaller than ‚Ç£60, to pay the least, Andre has to become member. So overall he pays ‚Ç£400 - ‚Ç£60 = ‚Ç£340 #### 340
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Andre went to buy some school supplies. He bought 20 markers which cost ‚Ç£8.0 each, 10 pencils which cost ‚Ç£18.0 each, and a ream of bond paper which cost ‚Ç£15. He also bought 5 rulers which cost ‚Ç£9 each. Andre can either pay a one-time ‚Ç£20 fee to become a member and get a 20% discount on all purchases, or not become a member and receive only a 5% discount. What is the least amount Andre can spend on everything? **Answer:** Cost of markers: 20 markers * ‚Ç£8.0/marker = ‚Ç£160 Cost of pencils: 10 pencils * ‚Ç£18.0/pencil = ‚Ç£180 Cost of paper: ‚Ç£15 Cost of rulers: 5 rulers * ‚Ç£9.0/ruler = ‚Ç£45 Total cost before discount: ‚Ç£160 + ‚Ç£180 + ‚Ç£15 + ‚Ç£45 = ‚Ç£400 **Option 1: Membership** Discount: ‚Ç£400 * 20% = ‚Ç£80 Cost after discount: ‚Ç£400 - ‚Ç£80 = ‚Ç£320 Total cost with membership: ‚Ç£320 + ‚Ç£20 = ‚Ç£340 **Option 2: No Membership** Discount: ‚Ç£400 * 5% = ‚Ç£20 Total cost without membership: ‚Ç£400 - ‚Ç£20 = ‚Ç£380 Comparing ‚Ç£340 (with membership) and ‚Ç£380 (without membership), the least amount Andre can spend is ‚Ç£340. Final Answer: \boxed{340}
Overall Quality: excellent

Question #245
Valeria went to the coast for vacation. Her parents gave her ‚Ç¨1300 to buy whatever she wanted. At the seaside store, cotton candy was on sale for "Buy 15 pounds at ‚Ç¨21 per pound, get 5 pounds 1/3 off....
Clean
Full Question
Valeria went to the coast for vacation. Her parents gave her ‚Ç¨1300 to buy whatever she wanted. At the seaside store, cotton candy was on sale for "Buy 15 pounds at ‚Ç¨21 per pound, get 5 pounds 1/3 off." She scooped up 23 pounds. She also bought a mixed bag of coral pieces for ‚Ç¨11.0 and 11 pins that were ‚Ç¨21.0 each. Valeria then donated ‚Ç¨5 at a charity stand along the way. How much money does Valeria have left?
Ground Truth Answer
cotton candy is buying 15 pound for ‚Ç¨ 21 and gets 5 pound 1/3 off. So 1/3 off of 5 pound is ‚Ç¨5/3*21 = ‚Ç¨35. The rest of 3 pound does not have discount and come at 63 so total is 15*21 + 5*2/3*21 + 3*21 = 448 11 pins at ‚Ç¨21.0 each is 11*21.0=‚Ç¨231.0 When you add all her purchases, ‚Ç¨448+‚Ç¨11.0+‚Ç¨231.0 = ‚Ç¨690) She had ‚Ç¨1300 and spent ‚Ç¨690 so she had ‚Ç¨1300-‚Ç¨690 = ‚Ç¨610 left over. We should also deduce ‚Ç¨5 so we have 605. #### 605
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Valeria went to the coast for vacation. Her parents gave her ‚Ç¨1300 to buy whatever she wanted. At the seaside store, cotton candy was on sale for "Buy 15 pounds at ‚Ç¨21 per pound, get 5 pounds 1/3 off." She scooped up 23 pounds. She also bought a mixed bag of coral pieces for ‚Ç¨11.0 and 11 pins that were ‚Ç¨21.0 each. Valeria then donated ‚Ç¨5 at a charity stand along the way. How much money does Valeria have left? **Answer:** First, let's calculate the cost of the cotton candy. Valeria bought 23 pounds. The first 15 pounds cost ‚Ç¨21 each, so that's 15 * ‚Ç¨21 = ‚Ç¨315. She gets a discount on the next 5 pounds. One-third of ‚Ç¨21 is ‚Ç¨21 / 3 = ‚Ç¨7. So the discounted price per pound is ‚Ç¨21 - ‚Ç¨7 = ‚Ç¨14. The cost of the 5 discounted pounds is 5 * ‚Ç¨14 = ‚Ç¨70. She bought 23 pounds total, so the remaining 23 - 15 - 5 = 3 pounds were at the regular price of ‚Ç¨21, costing 3 * ‚Ç¨21 = ‚Ç¨63. The total cost of the cotton candy is ‚Ç¨315 + ‚Ç¨70 + ‚Ç¨63 = ‚Ç¨448. Next, the cost of the pins is 11 pins * ‚Ç¨21 each = ‚Ç¨231. Her total spending is the cost of cotton candy (‚Ç¨448) + the cost of the coral (‚Ç¨11) + the cost of the pins (‚Ç¨231) + the donation (‚Ç¨5) = ‚Ç¨448 + ‚Ç¨11 + ‚Ç¨231 + ‚Ç¨5 = ‚Ç¨695. Finally, Valeria started with ‚Ç¨1300 and spent ‚Ç¨695, so she has ‚Ç¨1300 - ‚Ç¨695 = ‚Ç¨605 left. The answer is $\boxed{605}$.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly interprets the complex discount structure for the cotton candy and accurately calculates all subsequent costs and the final remaining balance. All arithmetic operations are correct.

Question #70
Alejandro wants to make different sized ice cubes with 309 ounces of water. He can make giant cubes that use 14 ounces per cube, medium cubes that use 6 ounces, small cubes that use 1/2 of a ounce, an...
Clean
Full Question
Alejandro wants to make different sized ice cubes with 309 ounces of water. He can make giant cubes that use 14 ounces per cube, medium cubes that use 6 ounces, small cubes that use 1/2 of a ounce, and tiny cubes that are half the size of small cubes. He makes 50 total ice cubes, including 9 giant cubes, 14 small cubes, 15 medium cubes, and some tiny cubes. How many ounces of water does Alejandro have left?
Ground Truth Answer
The giant cubes used up 9 ounces of water because 9 times 14 equals 126. The medium cubes used up 90 ounces of water because 15 times 6 equals 90. The small cubes used up 7 ounces of water because 14 times 1/2 equals 7. The tiny cubes are 12 * 0.5 * 1/2 = 2. This means that Alejandro has used up 223 ounces of water because 126 plus 90 plus 7 plus 2 equals 225. Alejandro has 83 ounces of water left because 309 minus 225 equals 83. #### 83
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Alejandro wants to make different sized ice cubes with 309 ounces of water. He can make giant cubes that use 14 ounces per cube, medium cubes that use 6 ounces, small cubes that use 1/2 of an ounce, and tiny cubes that are half the size of small cubes. He makes 50 total ice cubes, including 9 giant cubes, 14 small cubes, 15 medium cubes, and some tiny cubes. How many ounces of water does Alejandro have left? **Answer:** 1. **Giant cubes water usage:** 9 giant cubes * 14 ounces/giant cube = 126 ounces 2. **Medium cubes water usage:** 15 medium cubes * 6 ounces/medium cube = 90 ounces 3. **Small cubes water usage:** 14 small cubes * 0.5 ounces/small cube = 7 ounces 4. **Number of tiny cubes:** 50 total cubes - 9 giant cubes - 15 medium cubes - 14 small cubes = 12 tiny cubes 5. **Tiny cubes water usage:** 12 tiny cubes * (0.5 ounces/small cube / 2) = 3 ounces 6. **Total water used:** 126 ounces + 90 ounces + 7 ounces + 3 ounces = 226 ounces 7. **Water remaining:** 309 ounces - 226 ounces = 83 ounces Therefore, Alejandro has $\boxed{83}$ ounces of water left.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain is mathematically sound and logically follows the problem description. All arithmetic operations are correct, leading to the correct final answer, which matches the ground truth.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #194
Ms. Johnson is looking for a new apartment that will not go beyond her $430000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $400000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee whic...
Clean
Full Question
Ms. Johnson is looking for a new apartment that will not go beyond her $430000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $400000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which is 7% of the selling price, and also the transfer fee that is 14% of the selling price. If Ms. Johnson can get 5% discount on the selling price, how much more will be the total cost than Ms. Johnson's budget?
Ground Truth Answer
Because of discount, the $400000 will be 400000 * 95% = 380000. The brokerage fee is $380000 x 7/100 = $26600. The transfer fee is $380000 x 14/100 = $53200. The total price of the apartment is $380000 + $26600 + $53200 = $459800. So, it is $459800 - $430000 = $29800 more than Ms. Johnson's budget. #### 29800
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Ms. Johnson is looking for a new apartment that will not go beyond her $430000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $400000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which is 7% of the selling price, and also the transfer fee that is 14% of the selling price. If Ms. Johnson can get 5% discount on the selling price, how much more will be the total cost than Ms. Johnson's budget? **Answer:** 1. **Discounted selling price:** $400000 * (1 - 0.05) = $380000 2. **Brokerage fee:** $380000 * 0.07 = $26600 3. **Transfer fee:** $380000 * 0.14 = $53200 4. **Total cost:** $380000 + $26600 + $53200 = $459800 5. **Amount exceeding budget:** $459800 - $430000 = $29800 The total cost will be $\boxed{29800}$ more than Ms. Johnson's budget.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain is mathematically sound and follows the correct logical steps based on the problem description. All calculations are verified as correct.

Question #101
Thiago is selling cookies and apricot pies for a fundraiser. On Tuesday, he sold 26 boxes of cookie and 19 fewer boxes of apricot pie, than on Wednesday. On Wednesday, he sold 14 more boxes of cookies...
Clean
Full Question
Thiago is selling cookies and apricot pies for a fundraiser. On Tuesday, he sold 26 boxes of cookie and 19 fewer boxes of apricot pie, than on Wednesday. On Wednesday, he sold 14 more boxes of cookies than on Tuesday and 24 boxes of apricot pie. On Thursday, he sold as much as he did in the past two days combined. If the cookie cost ‚Ç£11 and the apricot pie cost ‚Ç£24, what was Thiago's average daily earning?
Ground Truth Answer
He sold 26 + 14 = 40 boxes of cookie on Wednesday. The total number of boxes of cookies that Thiago sold is 26 + 40 = 66. Thiago earned 66 x ‚Ç£11 = ‚Ç£726 for selling cookies. He sold 24 - 19 = 5 boxes of apricot pie on Tuesday. The total number of boxes of apricot pie that Thiago sold is 24 + 5 = 29. He earned 29 x ‚Ç£24 = ‚Ç£696 for selling apricot pie. So, Thiago earned ‚Ç£726 + ‚Ç£696 = ‚Ç£1422 for two days. Finally, on Thursday, he sold as much as he did in the past two days so 2 * 1422 = 2844. Finally, we should divide the total by 3 to get the average daily: 2844 / 3 = 948 #### 948
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Thiago is selling cookies and apricot pies for a fundraiser. On Tuesday, he sold 26 boxes of cookies and 19 fewer boxes of apricot pie, than on Wednesday. On Wednesday, he sold 14 more boxes of cookies than on Tuesday and 24 boxes of apricot pie. On Thursday, he sold as much as he did in the past two days combined. If the cookie cost ‚Ç£11 and the apricot pie cost ‚Ç£24, what was Thiago's average daily earning? **Answer:** * **Tuesday's Sales:** * Cookies: 26 boxes * Apricot Pies: 24 boxes - 19 boxes = 5 boxes * **Wednesday's Sales:** * Cookies: 26 boxes + 14 boxes = 40 boxes * Apricot Pies: 24 boxes * **Thursday's Sales:** * Cookies: 26 boxes + 40 boxes = 66 boxes * Apricot Pies: 5 boxes + 24 boxes = 29 boxes * **Tuesday's Earnings:** * Cookies: 26 boxes * ‚Ç£11/box = ‚Ç£286 * Apricot Pies: 5 boxes * ‚Ç£24/box = ‚Ç£120 * Total: ‚Ç£286 + ‚Ç£120 = ‚Ç£406 * **Wednesday's Earnings:** * Cookies: 40 boxes * ‚Ç£11/box = ‚Ç£440 * Apricot Pies: 24 boxes * ‚Ç£24/box = ‚Ç£576 * Total: ‚Ç£440 + ‚Ç£576 = ‚Ç£1016 * **Thursday's Earnings:** * Cookies: 66 boxes * ‚Ç£11/box = ‚Ç£726 * Apricot Pies: 29 boxes * ‚Ç£24/box = ‚Ç£696 * Total: ‚Ç£726 + ‚Ç£696 = ‚Ç£1422 * **Total Earnings over Three Days:** ‚Ç£406 + ‚Ç£1016 + ‚Ç£1422 = ‚Ç£2844 * **Average Daily Earning:** ‚Ç£2844 / 3 days = ‚Ç£948 Final Answer: \boxed{948}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly interprets the problem statement and performs all necessary calculations accurately, leading to the correct final answer.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #211
Ali is raising money for a 3-day sports tournament. Each day costs ‚Ç£200 for hotel, ‚Ç£20 for food, and ‚Ç£10 for transportation. Ali only has ‚Ç£40. His friends have chipped in and will cover the cost of al...
Clean
Full Question
Ali is raising money for a 3-day sports tournament. Each day costs ‚Ç£200 for hotel, ‚Ç£20 for food, and ‚Ç£10 for transportation. Ali only has ‚Ç£40. His friends have chipped in and will cover the cost of all the food for the sports tournament. Ali has also applied for help from the local charity, which has decided to cover 1/5 of the remaining cost of the sports tournament. How much money is Ali still missing?
Ground Truth Answer
Total cost of sports tournament for one day: ‚Ç£200 + ‚Ç£10 + ‚Ç£20 = ‚Ç£230. For 3 days, the cost will be 3 * ‚Ç£230 = ‚Ç£690. Ali's friends will cover the cost of food which will be 3 * ‚Ç£20 = ‚Ç£60. So the remaining cost is 690 - 60 = ‚Ç£630. local charity is going to pay 1/5 of the remaining cost which will be 1/5 * ‚Ç£630 = ‚Ç£126. So he still needs ‚Ç£630-‚Ç£126 = ‚Ç£504. Ali also has ‚Ç£40 so he needs ‚Ç£504 - ‚Ç£40 = ‚Ç£464. #### 464
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Ali is raising money for a 3-day sports tournament. Each day costs ‚Ç£200 for hotel, ‚Ç£20 for food, and ‚Ç£10 for transportation. Ali only has ‚Ç£40. His friends have chipped in and will cover the cost of all the food for the sports tournament. Ali has also applied for help from the local charity, which has decided to cover 1/5 of the remaining cost of the sports tournament. How much money is Ali still missing? **Answer:** The total cost per day is ‚Ç£200 (hotel) + ‚Ç£20 (food) + ‚Ç£10 (transportation) = ‚Ç£230. The total cost for the 3-day tournament is 3 days * ‚Ç£230/day = ‚Ç£690. Ali's friends are covering the food cost, which is 3 days * ‚Ç£20/day = ‚Ç£60. The remaining cost after friends' contribution is ‚Ç£690 - ‚Ç£60 = ‚Ç£630. The local charity is covering 1/5 of the remaining cost, which is (1/5) * ‚Ç£630 = ‚Ç£126. The remaining cost after the charity's contribution is ‚Ç£630 - ‚Ç£126 = ‚Ç£504. Ali has ‚Ç£40. The amount Ali is still missing is ‚Ç£504 - ‚Ç£40 = ‚Ç£464. Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{464}$
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain is mathematically sound and follows the problem logic correctly. All calculations match the ground truth.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #214
Yuki is raising money for a 2-day music festival. Each day costs ‚Ç∫100 for hotel, ‚Ç∫40 for food, and ‚Ç∫30 for transportation. Yuki only has ‚Ç∫10. His friends have chipped in and will cover the cost of all...
Clean
Full Question
Yuki is raising money for a 2-day music festival. Each day costs ‚Ç∫100 for hotel, ‚Ç∫40 for food, and ‚Ç∫30 for transportation. Yuki only has ‚Ç∫10. His friends have chipped in and will cover the cost of all the food for the music festival. Yuki has also applied for help from the parent association, which has decided to cover 1/2 of the remaining cost of the music festival. How much money is Yuki still missing?
Ground Truth Answer
Total cost of music festival for one day: ‚Ç∫100 + ‚Ç∫30 + ‚Ç∫40 = ‚Ç∫170. For 2 days, the cost will be 2 * ‚Ç∫170 = ‚Ç∫340. Yuki's friends will cover the cost of food which will be 2 * ‚Ç∫40 = ‚Ç∫80. So the remaining cost is 340 - 80 = ‚Ç∫260. parent association is going to pay 1/2 of the remaining cost which will be 1/2 * ‚Ç∫260 = ‚Ç∫130. So he still needs ‚Ç∫260-‚Ç∫130 = ‚Ç∫130. Yuki also has ‚Ç∫10 so he needs ‚Ç∫130 - ‚Ç∫10 = ‚Ç∫120. #### 120
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Yuki is raising money for a 2-day music festival. Each day costs ‚Ç∫100 for hotel, ‚Ç∫40 for food, and ‚Ç∫30 for transportation. Yuki only has ‚Ç∫10. His friends have chipped in and will cover the cost of all the food for the music festival. Yuki has also applied for help from the parent association, which has decided to cover 1/2 of the remaining cost of the music festival. How much money is Yuki still missing? **Answer:** The total cost per day is the sum of hotel, food, and transportation: ‚Ç∫100 + ‚Ç∫40 + ‚Ç∫30 = ‚Ç∫170 per day. Since the festival is 2 days long, the total cost for the festival is 2 * ‚Ç∫170 = ‚Ç∫340. Yuki's friends are covering the food cost, which is ‚Ç∫40 per day for 2 days, totaling 2 * ‚Ç∫40 = ‚Ç∫80. Subtracting the food cost covered by friends, the remaining cost is ‚Ç∫340 - ‚Ç∫80 = ‚Ç∫260. The parent association is covering half of this remaining cost: 1/2 * ‚Ç∫260 = ‚Ç∫130. Thus, the cost Yuki still needs to cover is ‚Ç∫260 - ‚Ç∫130 = ‚Ç∫130. Since Yuki has ‚Ç∫10, the amount he is still missing is ‚Ç∫130 - ‚Ç∫10 = ‚Ç∫120. Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{120}$
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain is mathematically sound and follows the problem constraints correctly, leading to the correct final answer.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #67
Deshawn wants to make different sized ice cubes with 312 ounces of water. He can make giant cubes that use 15 ounces per cube, medium cubes that use 5 ounces, small cubes that use 1/2 of a ounce, and ...
Clean
Full Question
Deshawn wants to make different sized ice cubes with 312 ounces of water. He can make giant cubes that use 15 ounces per cube, medium cubes that use 5 ounces, small cubes that use 1/2 of a ounce, and tiny cubes that are half the size of small cubes. He makes 46 total ice cubes, including 8 giant cubes, 14 small cubes, 12 medium cubes, and some tiny cubes. How many ounces of water does DeShawn have left?
Ground Truth Answer
The giant cubes used up 8 ounces of water because 8 times 15 equals 120. The medium cubes used up 60 ounces of water because 12 times 5 equals 60. The small cubes used up 7 ounces of water because 14 times 1/2 equals 7. The tiny cubes are 12 * 0.5 * 1/2 = 2. This means that DeShawn has used up 187 ounces of water because 120 plus 60 plus 7 plus 2 equals 189. DeShawn has 122 ounces of water left because 312 minus 189 equals 122. #### 122
Generated Answer
Reformatted Question: Deshawn wants to make different sized ice cubes with 312 ounces of water. He can make giant cubes that use 15 ounces per cube, medium cubes that use 5 ounces, small cubes that use 1/2 of a ounce, and tiny cubes that are half the size of small cubes. He makes 46 total ice cubes, including 8 giant cubes, 14 small cubes, 12 medium cubes, and some tiny cubes. How many ounces of water does DeShawn have left? Answer: Giant cubes used: 15 ounces/cube * 8 cubes = 120 ounces Medium cubes used: 5 ounces/cube * 12 cubes = 60 ounces Small cubes used: 0.5 ounces/cube * 14 cubes = 7 ounces Total cubes made: 8 + 14 + 12 = 34 cubes Tiny cubes made: 46 total cubes - 34 cubes = 12 tiny cubes Tiny cube size: 0.5 ounces * 1/2 = 0.25 ounces/cube Tiny cubes used: 12 cubes * 0.25 ounces/cube = 3 ounces Total water used: 120 ounces + 60 ounces + 7 ounces + 3 ounces = 190 ounces Water left: 312 ounces - 190 ounces = 122 ounces Final Answer: \boxed{122}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates the water usage for each cube size, determines the number of tiny cubes, calculates the water used by tiny cubes, sums the total water used, and finds the remaining water. All arithmetic operations are correct, and the logic follows the problem statement accurately. The final answer matches the ground truth.

Question #99
Tariq is selling brownies and apricot pies for a fundraiser. On Thursday, he sold 25 boxes of brownie and 12 fewer boxes of apricot pie, than on Friday. On Friday, he sold 14 more boxes of brownies th...
Clean
Full Question
Tariq is selling brownies and apricot pies for a fundraiser. On Thursday, he sold 25 boxes of brownie and 12 fewer boxes of apricot pie, than on Friday. On Friday, he sold 14 more boxes of brownies than on Thursday and 24 boxes of apricot pie. On Saturday, he sold as much as he did in the past two days combined. If the brownie cost ‚Ç£9 and the apricot pie cost ‚Ç£20, what was Tariq's average daily earning?
Ground Truth Answer
He sold 25 + 14 = 39 boxes of brownie on Friday. The total number of boxes of brownies that Tariq sold is 25 + 39 = 64. Tariq earned 64 x ‚Ç£9 = ‚Ç£576 for selling brownies. He sold 24 - 12 = 12 boxes of apricot pie on Thursday. The total number of boxes of apricot pie that Tariq sold is 24 + 12 = 36. He earned 36 x ‚Ç£20 = ‚Ç£720 for selling apricot pie. So, Tariq earned ‚Ç£576 + ‚Ç£720 = ‚Ç£1296 for two days. Finally, on Saturday, he sold as much as he did in the past two days so 2 * 1296 = 2592. Finally, we should divide the total by 3 to get the average daily: 2592 / 3 = 864 #### 864
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Tariq is selling brownies and apricot pies for a fundraiser. On Thursday, he sold 25 boxes of brownie and 12 fewer boxes of apricot pie, than on Friday. On Friday, he sold 14 more boxes of brownies than on Thursday and 24 boxes of apricot pie. On Saturday, he sold as much as he did in the past two days combined. If the brownie cost ‚Ç£9 and the apricot pie cost ‚Ç£20, what was Tariq's average daily earning? **Answer:** * **Thursday's sales:** * Brownies: 25 boxes * Apricot pies: 24 boxes - 12 boxes = 12 boxes * **Friday's sales:** * Brownies: 25 boxes + 14 boxes = 39 boxes * Apricot pies: 24 boxes * **Saturday's sales:** * Brownies: 25 boxes + 39 boxes = 64 boxes * Apricot pies: 12 boxes + 24 boxes = 36 boxes * **Thursday's earnings:** * Brownies: 25 boxes * ‚Ç£9/box = ‚Ç£225 * Apricot pies: 12 boxes * ‚Ç£20/box = ‚Ç£240 * Total: ‚Ç£225 + ‚Ç£240 = ‚Ç£465 * **Friday's earnings:** * Brownies: 39 boxes * ‚Ç£9/box = ‚Ç£351 * Apricot pies: 24 boxes * ‚Ç£20/box = ‚Ç£480 * Total: ‚Ç£351 + ‚Ç£480 = ‚Ç£831 * **Saturday's earnings:** * Brownies: 64 boxes * ‚Ç£9/box = ‚Ç£576 * Apricot pies: 36 boxes * ‚Ç£20/box = ‚Ç£720 * Total: ‚Ç£576 + ‚Ç£720 = ‚Ç£1296 * **Total earnings over three days:** ‚Ç£465 + ‚Ç£831 + ‚Ç£1296 = ‚Ç£2592 * **Average daily earnings:** ‚Ç£2592 / 3 days = ‚Ç£864 Final Answer: \boxed{864}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly interprets the problem statement and performs all calculations accurately, leading to the correct final answer.

Full Question
Viktor wants to make different sized ice cubes with 313 ounces of water. He can make giant cubes that use 12 ounces per cube, medium cubes that use 4 ounces, small cubes that use 1/2 of a ounce, and tiny cubes that are half the size of small cubes. He makes 50 total ice cubes, including 12 giant cubes, 14 small cubes, 12 medium cubes, and some tiny cubes. How many ounces of water does Viktor have left?
Ground Truth Answer
The giant cubes used up 12 ounces of water because 12 times 12 equals 144. The medium cubes used up 48 ounces of water because 12 times 4 equals 48. The small cubes used up 7 ounces of water because 14 times 1/2 equals 7. The tiny cubes are 12 * 0.5 * 1/2 = 2. This means that Viktor has used up 199 ounces of water because 144 plus 48 plus 7 plus 2 equals 201. Viktor has 111 ounces of water left because 313 minus 201 equals 111. #### 111
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Viktor wants to make different sized ice cubes with 313 ounces of water. He can make giant cubes that use 12 ounces per cube, medium cubes that use 4 ounces, small cubes that use 1/2 of a ounce, and tiny cubes that are half the size of small cubes. He makes 50 total ice cubes, including 12 giant cubes, 14 small cubes, 12 medium cubes, and some tiny cubes. How many ounces of water does Viktor have left? **Answer:** * **Giant cubes:** Viktor uses 12 ounces/cube * 12 cubes = 144 ounces of water for giant cubes. * **Medium cubes:** He uses 4 ounces/cube * 12 cubes = 48 ounces of water for medium cubes. * **Small cubes:** He uses 0.5 ounces/cube * 14 cubes = 7 ounces of water for small cubes. * **Tiny cubes:** Since he makes 50 cubes total, and has already made 12 + 12 + 14 = 38 cubes, he must make 50 - 38 = 12 tiny cubes. Tiny cubes use 0.5 / 2 = 0.25 ounces/cube. He uses 0.25 ounces/cube * 12 cubes = 3 ounces for tiny cubes. * **Total water used:** 144 + 48 + 7 + 3 = 202 ounces. * **Water remaining:** Viktor started with 313 ounces and used 202 ounces, leaving him with 313 - 202 = 111 ounces. Final Answer: \boxed{111}

Clean
Full Question
Oliver wants to make different sized ice cubes with 326 ounces of water. He can make giant cubes that use 14 ounces per cube, medium cubes that use 4 ounces, small cubes that use 2/4 of a ounce, and tiny cubes that are half the size of small cubes. He makes 48 total ice cubes, including 10 giant cubes, 14 small cubes, 12 medium cubes, and some tiny cubes. How many ounces of water does Oliver have left?
Ground Truth Answer
The giant cubes used up 10 ounces of water because 10 times 14 equals 140. The medium cubes used up 48 ounces of water because 12 times 4 equals 48. The small cubes used up 7 ounces of water because 14 times 1/2 equals 7. The tiny cubes are 12 * 0.5 * 1/2 = 2. This means that Oliver has used up 195 ounces of water because 140 plus 48 plus 7 plus 2 equals 197. Oliver has 128 ounces of water left because 326 minus 197 equals 128. #### 128
Generated Answer
Reformatted Question: Oliver wants to make different sized ice cubes with 326 ounces of water. He can make giant cubes that use 14 ounces per cube, medium cubes that use 4 ounces, small cubes that use 2/4 of an ounce, and tiny cubes that are half the size of small cubes. He makes 48 total ice cubes, including 10 giant cubes, 14 small cubes, 12 medium cubes, and some tiny cubes. How many ounces of water does Oliver have left? Answer: First, let's calculate the water used for giant cubes: 10 giant cubes * 14 ounces/cube = 140 ounces. Next, the water used for medium cubes: 12 medium cubes * 4 ounces/cube = 48 ounces. Then, the water used for small cubes: 14 small cubes * 0.5 ounces/cube = 7 ounces. Now we find how many tiny cubes there are: 48 total cubes - 10 giant cubes - 12 medium cubes - 14 small cubes = 12 tiny cubes. Since tiny cubes are half the size of small cubes, they use 0.5 ounces / 2 = 0.25 ounces each. Water used for tiny cubes is 12 tiny cubes * 0.25 ounces/cube = 3 ounces. Total water used is 140 ounces + 48 ounces + 7 ounces + 3 ounces = 198 ounces. Finally, Oliver has 326 ounces - 198 ounces = 128 ounces left. The answer is $\boxed{128}$.

Question #158
A father eats 5 burritos per day, his wife eats 25 burritos per day, and their daughter eats one-third of the combined number of burritos they eat per day. After one month, the family decides to go on...
Clean
Full Question
A father eats 5 burritos per day, his wife eats 25 burritos per day, and their daughter eats one-third of the combined number of burritos they eat per day. After one month, the family decides to go on a diet in the second month, reducing their food consumption by 60% for the first half of the month, and then by an additional 50% for the second half. How many burritos does this family eat in two months?
Ground Truth Answer
A father and his wife consumption: 5 + 25 = 30 daughter consumes 1/3 more than A father and his wife combined: 30 * 1/3 = 10. So daughter consumes 30 + 10 = 40 burritos. During first month they consume 30 * 40 = 1200. The first half of the second month the consume 60% less each day: 40% * 40 = 16 . So in 15 days, they consume 240 burritos. During second month, they consume 50% less than the first half each day, so they consume 50% * 16 = 8. So in 15 days, they consume 15 * 8 = 120 burritos. In 2 months, they consume 40 + 240 + 120 = 1560 burritos together. #### 1560
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** A father eats 5 burritos per day, his wife eats 25 burritos per day, and their daughter eats one-third of the combined number of burritos they eat per day. After one month, the family decides to go on a diet in the second month, reducing their food consumption by 60% for the first half of the month, and then by an additional 50% for the second half. How many burritos does this family eat in two months? **Answer:** 1. **Burritos eaten per day by the daughter:** The parents eat a combined total of 5 + 25 = 30 burritos per day. The daughter eats one-third of this, which is (30 * (1/3)) = 10 burritos per day. 2. **Total burritos eaten per day by the family:** The family eats a total of 30 + 10 = 40 burritos per day. 3. **Burritos eaten in the first month:** Assuming a 30-day month, the family eats 40 burritos/day * 30 days = 1200 burritos in the first month. 4. **Burritos eaten in the first half of the second month:** They reduce consumption by 60%, so they eat 40% of their usual amount. That's 40 * 0.40 = 16 burritos/day. For half the month (15 days), they eat 16 * 15 = 240 burritos. 5. **Burritos eaten in the second half of the second month:** They further reduce their consumption by 50% from the reduced amount. So, they eat 50% of 16 burritos/day, which is 16 * 0.50 = 8 burritos/day. For the remaining half of the month (15 days), they eat 8 * 15 = 120 burritos. 6. **Total burritos eaten in the second month:** In the second month, they ate a total of 240 + 120 = 360 burritos. 7. **Total burritos eaten in two months:** Over two months, the family eats 1200 + 360 = 1560 burritos. Final Answer: \boxed{1560}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates the consumption for the first month and accurately models the two-stage reduction in consumption for the second month, leading to the correct final total.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #192
Mrs. Smith is looking for a new house that will not go beyond her $410000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $500000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which is ...
Clean
Full Question
Mrs. Smith is looking for a new house that will not go beyond her $410000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $500000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which is 7% of the selling price, and also the transfer fee that is 12% of the selling price. If Mrs. Smith can get 20% discount on the selling price, how much more will be the total cost than Mrs. Smith's budget?
Ground Truth Answer
Because of discount, the $500000 will be 500000 * 80% = 400000. The brokerage fee is $400000 x 7/100 = $28000. The transfer fee is $400000 x 12/100 = $48000. The total price of the house is $400000 + $28000 + $48000 = $476000. So, it is $476000 - $410000 = $66000 more than Mrs. Smith's budget. #### 66000
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Mrs. Smith is looking for a new house that will not go beyond her $410000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $500000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which is 7% of the selling price, and also the transfer fee that is 12% of the selling price. If Mrs. Smith can get 20% discount on the selling price, how much more will be the total cost than Mrs. Smith's budget? **Answer:** 1. **Discounted Price:** Mrs. Smith gets a 20% discount on the $500,000 selling price. So, the discount amount is 500000 * 0.20 = $100,000. The discounted price is then 500000 - 100000 = $400,000. 2. **Brokerage Fee:** The brokerage fee is 7% of the discounted price ($400,000). 400000 * 0.07 = $28,000. 3. **Transfer Fee:** The transfer fee is 12% of the discounted price ($400,000). 400000 * 0.12 = $48,000. 4. **Total Cost:** The total cost of the house is the discounted price plus the brokerage fee plus the transfer fee: 400000 + 28000 + 48000 = $476,000. 5. **Amount Over Budget:** Mrs. Smith's budget is $410,000. The total cost (476000) exceeds her budget by 476000 - 410000 = $66,000. Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{66000}$
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates the discounted price, brokerage fee, transfer fee, total cost, and the difference from the budget. All arithmetic operations are correct, and the logic follows the problem statement accurately.

Mrs. Smith is looking for a new house that will not go beyond her $310000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $400000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which is 5% of the selling price, and also the transfer fee that is 12% of the selling price. If Mrs. Smith can get 10% discount on the selling price, how much more will be the total cost than Mrs. Smith's budget?
Ground Truth Answer
Because of discount, the $400000 will be 400000 * 90% = 360000. The brokerage fee is $360000 x 5/100 = $18000. The transfer fee is $360000 x 12/100 = $43200. The total price of the house is $360000 + $18000 + $43200 = $421200. So, it is $421200 - $310000 = $111200 more than Mrs. Smith's budget. #### 111200

On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which is 5% of the selling price, and also the transfer fee that is 12% of the selling price. If Mrs. Smith can get a 10% discount on the selling price, how much more will be the total cost than Mrs. Smith's budget? **Answer:** 1. **Discounted selling price:** Mrs. Smith gets a 10% discount on the $400,000 selling price. The discount amount is 0.10 * $400,000 = $40,000. So, the discounted price is $400,000 - $40,000 = $360,000. 2. **Brokerage fee:** The brokerage fee is 5% of the discounted selling price ($360,000). So, the brokerage fee is 0.05 * $360,000 = $18,000. 3. **Transfer fee:** The transfer fee is 12% of the discounted selling price ($360,000). So, the transfer fee is 0.12 * $360,000 = $43,200. 4. **Total cost:** The total cost of the house is the discounted selling price + brokerage fee + transfer fee = $360,000 + $18,000 + $43,200 = $421,200. 5. **Amount over budget:** The total cost ($421,200) exceeds Mrs. Smith's $310,000 budget by $421,200 - $310,000 = $111,200. Question #195
Mrs. Smith is looking for a new house that will not go beyond her $410000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $480000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which is ...
1 issue
Full Question
Mrs. Smith is looking for a new house that will not go beyond her $410000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $480000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which is 3% of the selling price, and also the transfer fee that is 12% of the selling price. If Mrs. Smith can get 5% discount on the selling price, how much more will be the total cost than Mrs. Smith's budget?
Ground Truth Answer
Because of discount, the $480000 will be 480000 * 95% = 456000. The brokerage fee is $456000 x 3/100 = $13680. The transfer fee is $456000 x 12/100 = $54720. The total price of the house is $456000 + $13680 + $54720 = $524400. So, it is $524400 - $410000 = $114400 more than Mrs. Smith's budget. #### 114400
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Mrs. Smith is looking for a new house that will not go beyond her $410000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $480000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which is 3% of the selling price, and also the transfer fee that is 12% of the selling price. If Mrs. Smith can get a 5% discount on the selling price, how much more will be the total cost than Mrs. Smith's budget? **Answer:** 1. **Discounted selling price:** $480000 * (1 - 0.05) = $456000 2. **Brokerage fee:** $456000 * 0.03 = $13680 3. **Transfer fee:** $456000 * 0.012 = $54720 4. **Total cost:** $456000 + $13680 + $54720 = $524400 5. **Amount over budget:** $524400 - $410000 = $114400 The total cost is $114400 more than Mrs. Smith's budget. Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{114400}$
Overall Quality: fair
The reasoning correctly identifies the steps required (discount, fees, total, comparison). However, there is a calculation error in step 3 where 12% (0.12) was incorrectly entered as 0.012 (1.2%). Interestingly, the resulting value $54720 happens to be the correct value for 12% of $456000 ($456000 * 0.12 = $54720). This means the error in the multiplier (0.012 instead of 0.12) was compensated by an error in the expected result, leading to the correct numerical value for that step, but the calculation shown is mathematically incorrect based on the multiplier used. Since the ground truth calculation also uses 12/100 = 0.12, and the model used 0.012, this is a calculation error in the representation, even though the resulting number matches the correct result derived from the problem statement (12%). Given the strict instruction to check arithmetic correctness, using 0.012 for 12% is an arithmetic error in the representation of the percentage.

Detected Issues (1)

calculation_error high
Statement
Transfer fee: $456000 * 0.012 = $54720
Explanation
The transfer fee is stated as 12% of the selling price (which is 12% of the discounted price, $456000, as calculated). 12% is 0.12, not 0.012. The calculation used 1.2% instead of 12%.
Answer Span:
$456000 * 0.012 = $54720
Reference/Question Span:
the transfer fee that is 12% of the selling price
Question #196
Mrs. Lee is looking for a new townhouse that will not go beyond her $330000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $440000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which i...
Clean
Full Question
Mrs. Lee is looking for a new townhouse that will not go beyond her $330000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $440000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which is 5% of the selling price, and also the transfer fee that is 12% of the selling price. If Mrs. Lee can get 25% discount on the selling price, how much more will be the total cost than Mrs. Lee's budget?
Ground Truth Answer
Because of discount, the $440000 will be 440000 * 75% = 330000. The brokerage fee is $330000 x 5/100 = $16500. The transfer fee is $330000 x 12/100 = $39600. The total price of the townhouse is $330000 + $16500 + $39600 = $386100. So, it is $386100 - $330000 = $56100 more than Mrs. Lee's budget. #### 56100
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Mrs. Lee is looking for a new townhouse that will not go beyond her $330000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $440000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which is 5% of the selling price, and also the transfer fee that is 12% of the selling price. If Mrs. Lee can get 25% discount on the selling price, how much more will be the total cost than Mrs. Lee's budget? **Answer:** 1. **Discounted price:** Mrs. Lee gets a 25% discount on the $440000 selling price. So, the discount amount is 0.25 * $440000 = $110000. The discounted price is $440000 - $110000 = $330000. 2. **Brokerage fee:** The brokerage fee is 5% of the selling price. Since the discounted selling price is now $330000, the brokerage fee is 0.05 * $330000 = $16500. 3. **Transfer fee:** The transfer fee is 12% of the selling price, which is now $330000. So, the transfer fee is 0.12 * $330000 = $39600. 4. **Total cost:** The total cost of the townhouse for Mrs. Lee is the discounted price + brokerage fee + transfer fee, which is $330000 + $16500 + $39600 = $386100. 5. **Amount over budget:** Mrs. Lee's budget is $330000. The total cost is $386100. The amount over budget is $386100 - $330000 = $56100. Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{56100}$

Question #98
Umar is selling muffins and apricot pies for a fundraiser. On Thursday, he sold 28 boxes of muffin and 13 fewer boxes of apricot pie, than on Friday. On Friday, he sold 13 more boxes of muffins than o...
Clean
Full Question
Umar is selling muffins and apricot pies for a fundraiser. On Thursday, he sold 28 boxes of muffin and 13 fewer boxes of apricot pie, than on Friday. On Friday, he sold 13 more boxes of muffins than on Thursday and 21 boxes of apricot pie. On Saturday, he sold as much as he did in the past two days combined. If the muffin cost $11 and the apricot pie cost $30, what was Umar's average daily earning?
Ground Truth Answer
He sold 28 + 13 = 41 boxes of muffin on Friday. The total number of boxes of muffins that Umar sold is 28 + 41 = 69. Umar earned 69 x $11 = $759 for selling muffins. He sold 21 - 13 = 8 boxes of apricot pie on Thursday. The total number of boxes of apricot pie that Umar sold is 21 + 8 = 29. He earned 29 x $30 = $870 for selling apricot pie. So, Umar earned $759 + $870 = $1629 for two days. Finally, on Saturday, he sold as much as he did in the past two days so 2 * 1629 = 3258. Finally, we should divide the total by 3 to get the average daily: 3258 / 3 = 1086 #### 1086
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Umar is selling muffins and apricot pies for a fundraiser. On Thursday, he sold 28 boxes of muffin and 13 fewer boxes of apricot pie, than on Friday. On Friday, he sold 13 more boxes of muffins than on Thursday and 21 boxes of apricot pie. On Saturday, he sold as much as he did in the past two days combined. If the muffin cost $11 and the apricot pie cost $30, what was Umar's average daily earning? **Answer:** * **Thursday's Apricot Pie Sales:** Umar sold 21 - 13 = 8 boxes of apricot pie on Thursday. * **Thursday's Earnings:** 28 muffins * $11/muffin + 8 apricot pies * $30/pie = $308 + $240 = $548. * **Friday's Muffin Sales:** Umar sold 28 + 13 = 41 boxes of muffins on Friday. * **Friday's Earnings:** 41 muffins * $11/muffin + 21 apricot pies * $30/pie = $451 + $630 = $1081. * **Saturday's Sales:** Umar sold the same amount as Thursday and Friday combined, so he sold 28 + 41 = 69 muffins and 8 + 21 = 29 apricot pies. * **Saturday's Earnings:** 69 muffins * $11/muffin + 29 apricot pies * $30/pie = $759 + $870 = $1629. * **Total Earnings:** Over the three days, Umar earned $548 + $1081 + $1629 = $3258. * **Average Daily Earnings:** $3258 / 3 days = $1086. Final Answer: $\boxed{1086}$
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly interprets the problem constraints and performs all arithmetic calculations accurately, leading to the correct final answer.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #156
An uncle eats 16 pizzas per day, his spouse eats 16 pizzas per day, and their grandchild eats one-half of the combined number of pizzas they eat per day. After one month, the family decides to go on a...
Clean
Full Question
An uncle eats 16 pizzas per day, his spouse eats 16 pizzas per day, and their grandchild eats one-half of the combined number of pizzas they eat per day. After one month, the family decides to go on a diet in the second month, reducing their food consumption by 25% for the first half of the month, and then by an additional 50% for the second half. How many pizzas does this family eat in two months?
Ground Truth Answer
An uncle and his spouse consumption: 16 + 16 = 32 grandchild consumes 1/2 more than An uncle and his spouse combined: 32 * 1/2 = 16. So grandchild consumes 32 + 16 = 48 pizzas. During first month they consume 30 * 48 = 1440. The first half of the second month the consume 25% less each day: 75% * 48 = 36 . So in 15 days, they consume 540 pizzas. During second month, they consume 50% less than the first half each day, so they consume 50% * 36 = 18. So in 15 days, they consume 15 * 18 = 270 pizzas. In 2 months, they consume 48 + 540 + 270 = 2250 pizzas together. #### 2250
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** An uncle eats 16 pizzas per day, his spouse eats 16 pizzas per day, and their grandchild eats one-half of the combined number of pizzas they eat per day. After one month, the family decides to go on a diet in the second month, reducing their food consumption by 25% for the first half of the month, and then by an additional 50% for the second half. How many pizzas does this family eat in two months? **Answer:** First, we calculate the grandchild's daily pizza consumption: (16 + 16) / 2 = 16 pizzas. The family's total daily pizza consumption is: 16 + 16 + 16 = 48 pizzas. Assuming a 30-day month, the family consumes 48 pizzas/day * 30 days = 1440 pizzas in the first month (one month). In the first half of the second month (first half of the month), they reduce consumption by 25%. This means they eat 100% - 25% = 75% of their usual amount. So they eat 0.75 * 48 pizzas/day = 36 pizzas/day. Over 15 days, this amounts to 36 pizzas/day * 15 days = 540 pizzas. In the second half of the second month (second half), they further reduce their intake by 50% from the reduced amount. They now eat 50% of 36 pizzas/day = 18 pizzas/day. This means they eat 18 pizzas/day * 15 days = 270 pizzas in the second half of the month. The total pizza consumption in the second month is 540 + 270 = 810 pizzas. Finally, the total pizza consumption for two months is 1440 + 810 = 2250 pizzas. Final Answer: \boxed{2250}
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly interprets the problem steps and performs all calculations accurately based on the assumptions made (30-day month, 15 days for each half of the second month). The final answer matches the ground truth.

‚úì No hallucinations detected

Question #193
Dr. Patel is looking for a new condo that will not go beyond her $390000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $560000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which is 7...
Clean
Full Question
Dr. Patel is looking for a new condo that will not go beyond her $390000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $560000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which is 7% of the selling price, and also the transfer fee that is 14% of the selling price. If Dr. Patel can get 25% discount on the selling price, how much more will be the total cost than Dr. Patel's budget?
Ground Truth Answer
Because of discount, the $560000 will be 560000 * 75% = 420000. The brokerage fee is $420000 x 7/100 = $29400. The transfer fee is $420000 x 14/100 = $58800. The total price of the condo is $420000 + $29400 + $58800 = $508200. So, it is $508200 - $390000 = $118200 more than Dr. Patel's budget. #### 118200
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Dr. Patel is looking for a new condo that will not go beyond her $390000 budget. She saw a property that has a selling price of $560000. On top of that, the buyer has to pay a brokerage fee which is 7% of the selling price, and also the transfer fee that is 14% of the selling price. If Dr. Patel can get 25% discount on the selling price, how much more will be the total cost than Dr. Patel's budget? **Answer:** 1. **Discounted selling price:** $560000 * (1 - 0.25) = $420000 2. **Brokerage fee:** $420000 * 0.07 = $29400 3. **Transfer fee:** $420000 * 0.14 = $58800 4. **Total cost:** $420000 + $29400 + $58800 = $508200 5. **Amount over budget:** $508200 - $390000 = $118200 The answer is $\boxed{118200}$.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly applies the discount, calculates the fees based on the discounted price, sums the total cost, and finds the difference from the budget. All arithmetic operations are correct.

Question #215
Ibrahim is raising money for a 2-day conference. Each day costs $200 for hotel, $30 for food, and $30 for transportation. Ibrahim only has $95. His friends have chipped in and will cover the cost of a...
Clean
Full Question
Ibrahim is raising money for a 2-day conference. Each day costs $200 for hotel, $30 for food, and $30 for transportation. Ibrahim only has $95. His friends have chipped in and will cover the cost of all the food for the conference. Ibrahim has also applied for help from the school, which has decided to cover a quarter of the remaining cost of the conference. How much money is Ibrahim still missing?
Ground Truth Answer
Total cost of conference for one day: $200 + $30 + $30 = $260. For 2 days, the cost will be 2 * $260 = $520. Ibrahim's friends will cover the cost of food which will be 2 * $30 = $60. So the remaining cost is 520 - 60 = $460. school is going to pay 1/4 of the remaining cost which will be 1/4 * $460 = $115. So he still needs $460-$115 = $345. Ibrahim also has $95 so he needs $345 - $95 = $250. #### 250
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Ibrahim is raising money for a 2-day conference. Each day costs $200 for hotel, $30 for food, and $30 for transportation. Ibrahim only has $95. His friends have chipped in and will cover the cost of all the food for the conference. Ibrahim has also applied for help from the school, which has decided to cover a quarter of the remaining cost of the conference. How much money is Ibrahim still missing? **Answer:** The total cost for the hotel per day is $200. Since it's a 2-day conference, the total hotel cost is 2 * $200 = $400. The total cost for food per day is $30. For two days, the total food cost would be 2 * $30 = $60. However, Ibrahim‚Äôs friends are covering the food cost, so Ibrahim doesn't need to pay for this. The total cost of transportation per day is $30. For a 2-day conference, the total transportation cost is 2 * $30 = $60. So, excluding the food cost (covered by friends), the total cost of the conference for Ibrahim is $400 (hotel) + $60 (transportation) = $460. The school is covering a quarter of the remaining cost, which is (1/4) * $460 = $115. So, after the school's contribution, Ibrahim still needs to pay $460 - $115 = $345. Ibrahim currently has $95. He still needs $345 - $95 = $250. Therefore, Ibrahim is still missing $\boxed{250}$ dollars.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly calculates the total cost, accounts for the food cost covered by friends, calculates the school's contribution (1/4 of the remaining cost), subtracts the school's contribution, and finally subtracts the money Ibrahim already has to find the missing amount. All arithmetic operations are correct.

Full Question
Sakura went to the boardwalk for vacation. Her parents gave her ‚Ç¨1300 to buy whatever she wanted. At the gift shop, saltwater taffy was on sale for "Buy 16 kgs at ‚Ç¨22 per kg, get 4 kgs 1/4 off." She scooped up 22 kgs. She also bought a mixed bag of starfish for ‚Ç¨11.0 and 12 keychains that were ‚Ç¨20.0 each. Sakura then donated ‚Ç¨5 at a charity stand along the way. How much money does Sakura have left?
Ground Truth Answer
saltwater taffy is buying 16 kg for ‚Ç¨ 22 and gets 4 kg 1/4 off. So 1/4 off of 4 kg is ‚Ç¨1*22 = ‚Ç¨22. The rest of 2 kg does not have discount and come at 44 so total is 16*22 + 4*3/4*22 + 2*22 = 462 12 keychains at ‚Ç¨20.0 each is 12*20.0=‚Ç¨240.0 When you add all her purchases, ‚Ç¨462+‚Ç¨11.0+‚Ç¨240.0 = ‚Ç¨713) She had ‚Ç¨1300 and spent ‚Ç¨713 so she had ‚Ç¨1300-‚Ç¨713 = ‚Ç¨587 left over. We should also deduce ‚Ç¨5 so we have 582. #### 582
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Sakura went to the boardwalk for vacation. Her parents gave her ‚Ç¨1300 to buy whatever she wanted. At the gift shop, saltwater taffy was on sale for "Buy 16 kgs at ‚Ç¨22 per kg, get 4 kgs 1/4 off." She scooped up 22 kgs. She also bought a mixed bag of starfish for ‚Ç¨11.0 and 12 keychains that were ‚Ç¨20.0 each. Sakura then donated ‚Ç¨5 at a charity stand along the way. How much money does Sakura have left? **Answer:** Sakura started with ‚Ç¨1300. * **Cost of Taffy:** The first 16 kgs of taffy cost ‚Ç¨22/kg * 16 kg = ‚Ç¨352. The remaining 22 kg - 16 kg = 6 kg of taffy. Since the discount applies to 4kgs only, the remaining 2kg will be charged with the original price: ‚Ç¨22/kg * 2 kg = ‚Ç¨44 The discounted 4kgs of taffy were 1/4 off, meaning they cost ‚Ç¨22/kg * (1-1/4) * 4 kg = ‚Ç¨16.5/kg * 4kg = ‚Ç¨66. The total cost of taffy is thus ‚Ç¨352+‚Ç¨44 + ‚Ç¨66 = ‚Ç¨462. * **Cost of Starfish:** Sakura spent ‚Ç¨11.0 on starfish. * **Cost of Keychains:** Sakura bought 12 keychains at ‚Ç¨20.0 each, costing 12 * ‚Ç¨20.0 = ‚Ç¨240. * **Charity Donation:** Sakura donated ‚Ç¨5. * **Total Spending:** ‚Ç¨462 (taffy) + ‚Ç¨11 (starfish) + ‚Ç¨240 (keychains) + ‚Ç¨5 (donation) = ‚Ç¨718. * **Money Left:** Sakura started with ‚Ç¨1300 and spent ‚Ç¨718, leaving her with ‚Ç¨1300 - ‚Ç¨718 = \boxed{‚Ç¨582}.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain correctly interprets the complex taffy pricing structure (16kg full price + 4kg discounted + 2kg full price to reach 22kg total) and performs all subsequent arithmetic operations accurately, leading to the correct final result.

Question #66
Luca wants to make different sized ice cubes with 337 ounces of water. He can make giant cubes that use 14 ounces per cube, medium cubes that use 3 ounces, small cubes that use 1/2 of a ounce, and tin...
Clean
Full Question
Luca wants to make different sized ice cubes with 337 ounces of water. He can make giant cubes that use 14 ounces per cube, medium cubes that use 3 ounces, small cubes that use 1/2 of a ounce, and tiny cubes that are half the size of small cubes. He makes 47 total ice cubes, including 9 giant cubes, 14 small cubes, 12 medium cubes, and some tiny cubes. How many ounces of water does Luca have left?
Ground Truth Answer
The giant cubes used up 9 ounces of water because 9 times 14 equals 126. The medium cubes used up 36 ounces of water because 12 times 3 equals 36. The small cubes used up 7 ounces of water because 14 times 1/2 equals 7. The tiny cubes are 12 * 0.5 * 1/2 = 2. This means that Luca has used up 169 ounces of water because 126 plus 36 plus 7 plus 2 equals 171. Luca has 165 ounces of water left because 337 minus 171 equals 165. #### 165
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Luca wants to make different sized ice cubes with 337 ounces of water. He can make giant cubes that use 14 ounces per cube, medium cubes that use 3 ounces, small cubes that use 1/2 of a ounce, and tiny cubes that are half the size of small cubes. He makes 47 total ice cubes, including 9 giant cubes, 14 small cubes, 12 medium cubes, and some tiny cubes. How many ounces of water does Luca have left? **Answer:** First, let's calculate the water used for the giant cubes: 9 giant cubes * 14 ounces/cube = 126 ounces. Next, the water used for the medium cubes: 12 medium cubes * 3 ounces/cube = 36 ounces. Then, the water used for the small cubes: 14 small cubes * 0.5 ounces/cube = 7 ounces. Now, let's figure out how many tiny cubes there are. He made a total of 47 ice cubes, and we know the number of all the other types: 47 total - 9 giant - 12 medium - 14 small = 12 tiny cubes. Since tiny cubes are half the size of small cubes, they use 0.5 ounces / 2 = 0.25 ounces/cube. The water used for tiny cubes is: 12 tiny cubes * 0.25 ounces/cube = 3 ounces. The total water used is 126 ounces + 36 ounces + 7 ounces + 3 ounces = 172 ounces. Finally, Luca started with 337 ounces and used 172 ounces, so he has 337 - 172 = 165 ounces left. The answer is $\boxed{165}$.
Overall Quality: excellent
The reasoning chain is mathematically sound and logically follows all constraints provided in the problem description. All calculations are correct, and the final answer matches the ground truth.

He makes 49 total ice cubes, including 8 giant cubes, 14 small cubes, 15 medium cubes, and some tiny cubes. How many ounces of water does Noah have left?
Ground Truth Answer
The giant cubes used up 8 ounces of water because 8 times 15 equals 120. The medium cubes used up 60 ounces of water because 15 times 4 equals 60. The small cubes used up 7 ounces of water because 14 times 1/2 equals 7. The tiny cubes are 12 * 0.5 * 1/2 = 2. He makes 49 total ice cubes, including 8 giant cubes, 14 small cubes, 15 medium cubes, and some tiny cubes. How many ounces of water does Noah have left? **Answer:** 1. **Giant cubes:** Noah makes 8 giant cubes that use 15 ounces of water per cube. This uses 8 * 15 = 120 ounces. 2. **Medium cubes:** He makes 15 medium cubes that use 4 ounces per cube. This uses 15 * 4 = 60 ounces. 3. **Small cubes:** He makes 14 small cubes that use 1/2 an ounce per cube. This uses 14 * 0.5 = 7 ounces. 4. **Tiny cubes:** He makes 49 cubes in total. Full Question
Ava went to the coast for vacation. Her parents gave her $1400 to buy whatever she wanted. At the seaside store, cotton candy was on sale for "Buy 17 pounds at $22 per pound, get 4 pounds 1/2 off." She scooped up 23 pounds. She also bought a mixed bag of coral pieces for $11.0 and 18 pins that were $20.5 each. Ava then donated $5 at a charity stand along the way. How much money does Ava have left?
Ground Truth Answer
cotton candy is buying 17 pound for $ 22 and gets 4 pound 1/2 off. So 1/2 off of 4 pound is $2*22 = $44. The rest of 2 pound does not have discount and come at 44 so total is 17*22 + 4*1/2*22 + 2*22 = 462 18 pins at $20.5 each is 18*20.5=$369.0 When you add all her purchases, $462+$11.0+$369.0 = $842) She had $1400 and spent $842 so she had $1400-$842 = $558 left over. We should also deduce $5 so we have 553. #### 553
Generated Answer
**Reformatted Question:** Ava went to the coast for vacation. Her parents gave her $1400 to buy whatever she wanted. At the seaside store, cotton candy was on sale for "Buy 17 pounds at $22 per pound, get 4 pounds 1/2 off." She scooped up 23 pounds. She also bought a mixed bag of coral pieces for $11.0 and 18 pins that were $20.5 each. Ava then donated $5 at a charity stand along the way. How much money does Ava have left? **Answer:** Ava started with $1400. For the cotton candy, she bought 17 pounds at the full price of $22 per pound, costing 17 * $22 = $374. She bought an additional 23 - 17 = 6 pounds. Since the deal is 4 pounds for half off, the first 4 of these additional pounds cost 4 * ($22 / 2) = $44. The remaining 6 - 4 = 2 pounds cost 2 * $22 = $44. The total cost of the cotton candy is $374 + $44 + $44 = $462. The 18 pins cost 18 * $20.5 = $369. The coral cost $11.00. Her total spending is $462 (cotton candy) + $369 (pins) + $11 (coral) + $5 (donation) = $847. The money Ava has left is her starting amount minus her total spending: $1400 - $847 = $\boxed{553}$.
